[The following was published here on Wednesday, 17 February 2016, at 11:30 AM.] 

OK, Fellow Synergist! 

I'm delighted to advise that we're presenting our ambitious Health Maker Lab "Floor Plan" at this evening's Meetup Event. 

To give you a "flavor taste," here's a zoom-in on our HML HEALTH CENTRAL---the heart and hub of our physical spaces. All our other HML activities and Action Centers are clustered around Health Central---which is completely surrounded by a kind of "ring" hallway that accesses other core areas. 

[Copyright Land Grant 2016. All rights reserved.]

You'll see Health Central sub-titled "HML's Community Hub, Creativity Lounge & Coffee House." We've labeled some of Central's key stations (clockwise from upper right): IDJ (Idea DiskJockey), Power Bar (refreshments & food), Healthnographer (idea capture) and Beans & Balls (relaxed cogitation and conversation). 

These are just some of the novel HML concepts we'll unveil and explain this evening. 

As ever, we'll be hoping to elicit your good critiques and added-value ideas.

WeWork Tech---our co-host---is graciously providing beer and pizza this evening. We pledge to feed you body and mind and spirit...come join-in!!

LAND 

Founder, 3DP Media & 
Health Maker Lab

[Please let me repeat a couple of important PS.s...]

PS. If you've yet to make it out to one of our rich content, radical context Meetups, consider this one. We will have a number of "guests" in from WeWork Labs at Dumbo Heights. These are early-stage 'Preneurs who are curious about what we're doing in the LifeSci space. After all, the folks we're collaborating/co-hosting with at the WeWork Tech Meetup enthused: "Wow, very interesting meetup!" [The following was published here on Tuesday, 16 February 2016, at 3 PM.] 

Hi, Synergist! 

One of the great means to spread the Health Maker Lab "word" is to catch the (editorial) "eye" of an important media platform.

Well, earlier this afternoon, Technical.ly Brooklyn---part of the stable of mostly Mid-Atlantic "Technical.ly covered" cities---published a piece on HML entitled:

"Why these citizen-scientists are launching a nonprofit maker lab focused on health!"

Corporate Technical.ly's tagline is "Better cities through technology." As a mantra, most of you---I suspect---could happily chant along with that informed sentiment. And, that, too, is what Health Maker Lab is all about. Health and Healthcare betterment for our diverse citizenry in Brooklyn and NYC at large.

Enjoy the read. You'll see that are new and informative ideas in the story. (Hey, it's a "guest post;" and as a journo, I wrote it myself...with care, added-value and enthusiasm!)

Hope to see you at our February Meetup tomorrow (17 Feb) evening. We're unveiling our HML "Floor Plan"...a serious MILESTONE---revelatory and disruptive! Come join-in!

[The following was published here on Friday, 12 February 2016, at 8 AM.] 

Good (and gelid) Morning, Synergist!


Maybe you should just burrow down deeper under your covers... And, muse on how we're going to educate, entertain and inspire you at our up-coming Health Maker Lab-centric meetup... (That's Wednesday, 17 February at WeWork Dumbo Heights.)

+++

Last night I was out in my fur-hood-up parka to Jonathan Hirschman's latest MakeIt NYC Meetup. We convened at the new and nifty Impact Hub New York. This is a CoWorker by day that does events in the evening---on Broadway just south of Canal in Manh. 

Jonathan and MakeIt NYC curated a great event with five Maker-centric presenters---including my old chum (and newest Health Maker Lab Advisory Council member) JF Brandon of BotFactory. 

JF is Marketing Guru of BotFactory Inc. (I also consider Meister Brandon to be one of the geniuses of the early 3DP movement here in NYC.) BotFactory is the BK-born & bred (mothered by NYU-Poly) PCB---Printed Circuit Board, for you LifeSci folks---factory on your desktop. (Think "3D printing" your entire circuit---including traces, solder paste and pick-&-place of components---via their Squink product: YOWZA!) 

Almost every hardware device in existence now aspires to built-in intelligence, robotic inclinations and IoT (Internet of Things) "cloudy" connectivity. Most of those attributes reside on a circuit board. So, the flexibility, speed, iterative-ness and security of rolling your own component-laden PCB is a major advantage in such overweening challenges as Time To Market...

+++


Since you're known by the company you keep, please let me update you on our Health Maker Lab Advisory Council.

In the Not-for-Profit world---when you're a newly launched NfP "startup"---your sponsor-able bona fides include the quality of your true believers and proactive adherents. Ours ARE outstanding...and we're honored to enjoy their attention, support and faith in our mission. 

Here is our current (and growing!) official Advisory Council list (in alphabetical order):

Jonathan Askin, Technology Law Professor, Founder/Director, Brooklyn Law Incubator & Policy (BLIP) Clinic, Brooklyn Law School. Innovation Catalyst for the Brooklyn Law Center (CUBE) for Urban Business Entrepreneurship;

Sarah Boisvert, Chief 3DPrinting Officer, Potomac Photonics, Inc. Fellow, Laser Institute of America. Founder, DigiFabCon (Digital Fabrication Convention), 22 & 23 April 2016, Cambridge, MA;

JF Brandon, VP Sales & Marketing, BotFactory Inc., the Brooklyn-born & bred (mothered by NYU-Poly) PCB---Printed Circuit Board---factory on your desktop; 

John Coghlan, Founder/Principal, DUMBO Startup Lab;

Matt Lipschutz, former Meetup Board Member, Hack Manhattan. Co-Founder, new transport-admissions system startup;

Jon Luongo, MS, CCLS, Child Life Specialist, Maimonides Infants & Children's Hospital;

Aaron Roy, Head of Operations & Strategy, 3DPrinterOS, innovators in 3DP education & enterprise 3D Printing management platforms;

Conor Russomanno, Co-Founder & CEO of OpenBCI & Organizer of the new NeuroTechNYC Meetup;


David Solomonoff, President, New York Chapter, Internet Society; 

Victor Ty, Pediatric Radiation Oncology RN at Maimonides Medical Center; Health Maker in LEGO Medical & LEGO 3D Medical Designs;  

Thor Snilsberg, Executive Director, CityScience: committed to raising the quality of science education (STEM) and supporting environmental stewardship using the natural and built environments as laboratories for active learning.

+++

We're delighted to showcase our Council of leaders---and will update you as we add new members!


LAND 

Founder, 3DP Media & 
Health Maker Lab

[The following was published here on Wednesday, 10 February 2016, at 10 AM.]


Good Morning, Synergist!

From my "sneak peek" email to you and our Community of last night, you know that we're now (1) convening our February Meetup on Wednesday, the 17th; (2) enjoying the Venue-Sponsorship of BRAND-NEW WeWork Dumbo Heights; and (3) prepping to present our Health Maker Lab (HML) latest-report to you. 

This HCx3DP Meetup agenda will include the roll-out of our totally novel---and highly compelling!---Lab "floor plan." With our HML plan, we're pitching a VERY Big Tent. For some very good reasons. And, I'll explain why on 17 February...

I'm confident you'll find we're designing an environment and ecosystem that will foster Bio-Making, Health-Solving and Life-Enhancing at the Community level---however you "size" YOUR Community of interest.

First and foremost, Health Maker Lab will help grow rich and fecund creativity---YOURS!

Synergists, Bio is the new Black...and it's also the new Gold. So---as a Not-for-Profit---your HML is driving to empower your Citizen Science. In the surety that our Common-Good support will buttress your business building and/or social commerce. For the betterment of all...

[The following was published here on Tuesday, 26 January 2016, at 11:45 AM.]


Dear Synergist!

Look forward to seeing you tonight (Tuesday, 26 January) at CityScience. (That’s at 6:30 to 8:30 PM, Suite #403, 68 Jay Street, DUMBO, Brooklyn.) Hey, we'll be showing the first Rev of our prototype Health Maker Lab (HML) "Floor Plan." This design/layout will spotlight what our current prototype Lab may "look like”...and DO.

We'll also review our new Donor pitch-deck. And, also take a look at our LabFan Partner/Donor "Get Started" program. I'm also going to encourage audience participants to exchange and brainstorm real-time on some of our important and evolving HML issues and opportunities.

(Please RSVP and kindly donate your nominal admission fee on this event page.)

We're accelerating; come for the exhilarating ride...!!

LAND

Founder, 3DP Media & 
Health Maker Lab

PS. IF you can’t make it out to our Meetup this evening in person, we’re going to Live Stream the event. So, link here to HML’s LiveStream (OR, insert this URL in your browser: http://livestream.com/openarmsstudio/events/4741009) between 6:30 & 6:45 PM this evening. (Of course, nothing beats being with us in person for an enriching experience…)


+++

[The following was published here on Monday, 25 January 2016, at 3:30 PM.] 


Dear Synergist!

Tomorrow evening---Tuesday, 26 January, at 6:30 PM---we roll out our red carpet and invite you in to plan, progress and “play” with us to continue advancing Health Maker Lab (HML). (CityScience is venue-hosting us at their offices at 68 Jay Street, Suite #403, DUMBO.)

Tomorrow night---AND in this email---we’ll also explain how you can become a LabFan. Your use of HML's LabFan Donor-Starter Promo Kit will benefit your own organization while benefiting HML.

HML’s LabFan is a compelling means for your organization to get to know---and be known by!---Health Maker Lab’s important and growing Community of Health players. Ours is a broad, nonprofit, Health-enhancing mission and we proffer a Big Tent “welcome” of Healthcare diversity.

HML’s unique marketplace-positioning presents LabFan-program participants with targeted and effective means to access our segments’ decision-makers. While, at the same time, enhancing the well-being of many NYC local and City-wide communities. Further---via LabFan---your organization will learn from, and collaborate with, us for mutual betterment going forward. 

Plus---as a Founding LabFan---you’ll have “first-refusal” opportunities for taking precedent-advantage of future HML promotions.

Our LabFan program is low-cost and low-risk---while delivering high rewards to your company or group. That includes superior ROI to buttress your "early supporter" status. We've created LabFan to advance your organization’s interest in accessing our present and prospective HML Community. All while creating goodwill for you and show-casing your positive profile.

So, come join-in with us tomorrow evening in person for our proven mix of Health Maker Lab news, ideas, discussion and exchange around our common interests. (RSVP on this page and kindly donate a nominal admission fee.) We’ll talk more about LabFan at Tuesday night’s event. But---if you’d like more right now---please read on below.

Land

Organizer, “HCx3DP Meetup NY” &
Founder, Health Maker Lab

+++

HML's LabFan Donor-Starter Promo Kit.

Please let me outline how LabFan would work---for both our organizations---via our latest introductory Outline here.

Become a "LabFan" Leader: Gain from Founding-LabFan participation in support of HML development via PR, promotion and positioning within our innovative Program:

(A.)  Get involved and inspired (see specifics below): garner business gains (hard and soft) from our HML community's social commerce and common-good advancement.

(B.)  Help grow our HML Community (for your benefit and ours): make attendance at our events free for HML participants via donations by your LabFan Leader organization.

(C.)  Build interest, base and clout for both our innovative HML Program AND your LabFan organization.

(D.)  Micro support delivers Macro fostering: Join us---early and cost-effectively---at $500 per month for three months of trial LabFan status. (Want even more compelling terms? Invest three months up front for $1,275---instead of $1,500 over three months.)

(E.)  After three months, decide whether a deeper relationship with HML is important to your organization's goals. Then---if we've build goodwill with you---consider moving up to an appropriate "Founding" Donor level.

+++

+++

As promised in Item (A.) above, here are our initial "specifics" of "HML LabFan Donor Features ->>> Benefits"---delivering benefit/ROIs of customer-goodwill and more---to early-adopter/trial Donor "LabFans": 

(1) HML LabFan-Community positive public positioning ->>> LabFan-participating Organizations will enjoy appropriate showcasing as a leader in the innovative HML Community; 

(2) Appropriate promotion on HML Web site or custom SocMed Community site ->>> regular "collaborator" spotlighting of LabFan support for HML Community interests;

(3) Supported LabFan Web-site page or Hosted Social Network/SocMed exposure ->>> LabFan-created appropriate/curated showcasing for HML Community promo purposes;

(4) LabFan created & delivered (HML-curated, hosted & intro'ed) presentations at HML events ->>> enables LabFan added-value "story-telling" for HML Community betterment;

(5) LabFan Member-created & manned Mini-Exhibit tabletop displays at HML events ->>> enables LabFan added-value product & service "Show & Tell" for HML Community delight;

(6) LG provides LabFan-appropriate media coverage ->>> depending on LabFan Organization news "production," LG will freelance articles to sector-selected media vehicles, at one per month;

(7) LG provides LabFan eIntros to appropriate players in the "Big Tent" HML marketplace ->>> LG knowledge of player interests promises relationship-development matchmaking;

(8) LabFan Org-sponsored (added cost to participants) & HML-led Tours of Meetups, Maker Spaces & Facilities of HML-Community Interest ->>> primary field-research & relationship building.

+++

Dear Synergist, I hope you have found our LabFan Program introduction above---"LabFan" Leader outline and LabFan Donor-Starter Promo Kit "Features & Benefits"---compelling. Especially for the very-low, early-adopter/Donor cost. Plus, the added opportunity to be involved---at our Health Maker Lab “kick-off”---in an innovative and promising program for better commercial and common-good Health futures for all our involved communities.

---LG

[End]

+++


[The following was published here on Saturday, 23 January 2016, at 11 AM.] 

…AND, Greetings---Synergist---from the Blizzard of 2016 here in Tech-Centric Brooklyn!

[I’m writing to you from my home office --- in our DUMBO loft apartment overlooking the Brooklyn Bridge and Downtown Manhattan. The weather conditions ARE fulfilling the meteorological definition of “blizzard.” Semi “white-out” visibility through the high-wind driven horizontally blowing snow. Our accumulation is forecast to be ~2 inches per hour for much of the rest of the day. I can hear the muffled scrapping of plow-blades on BQE and Bridge roadways below about every 7 or 8 minutes. Who knows what the total snow-fall will measure in our neighborhood… Still---like my local Grandsons---I’m eager to get out in it…at least for a time…!!]

Now, below is the Health Maker Lab (HML) update I promised you in our most-recent emailed HML news of 19 January.

Many of our new, official Advisory Council members will be participating at our Tuesday, 26 January, HCx3DP Meetup/Health Maker Lab Review & Workshop (#8).

Please come out and join-in with your enthusiasm and ideas at CitySci. We're planning to address---as a group---a number of issues and opportunities during this Meetup. (Please RSVP and donate on this Page.) We'd love you help!

LAND 
Organizer, "HCx3DP Meetup NY" & 
Founder, Health Maker Lab

+++


HML News: A Review at the End & Beginning of 2015/16 [you may have already gotten updates about some of these doings...] ---

To encourage your continued interest to join-in our accelerating success --- which will also be yours! --- here's our latest HML News:

(A) City Science Venue-Hosts HCx3DP/HML Again (confirming our connection to important players) ---

On Tuesday, 26 January, CitySci will host our next "HCx3DP Meetup NY"/Health Maker Lab Report & Workshop. We'll be back at City Science here in DUMBO---for the third time! CitySci---a STEM-Ed NfP using the City as an education venue---is also one of our top STEM-Partners. Their continued pro bono support bodes well for our strengthening relationship.

(B) Our First Major Corporate Donor ---

3DPrinterOS---creator of a Cloud-based, Open, 3DP Operating System---has pledged $30K worth of 3D printers.

(C) A New Director Accepts a Seat --- 

Aaron Roy, Director of Strategy & Operations at 3DPrinterOS, has now joined our Board. 

(D) Another Talented and Enthusiastic Volunteer ---

Gianna Curcio---Mechanical Engineer, Digirati, 3DP Technician for the VA/Manhattan & a Digital Artist---joins our Videographer, Marcin Kulesza, to help out.

(E) Meeting, on 11 January, with NYU-Tandon at MetroTech Center, Downtown BK ---

I met with the NYU-Tandon's (new name of the NYU {née Polytechnic} School of Engineering) Vice Dean for Research, Innovation and Entrepreneurship Kurt Becker---and an old friend---on Monday, 11 January. 

I had multiple goals for this meeting. And, a concluding slide-full of "asks!" But, my first objective was to interest NYU-Tandon in hosting our physical HML prototype space. In exchange for a novel, turnkey Lab replete with major players, mentors, trainers, lecturers and eTinkers---with strategic Healthcare disciplines, innovations, equipment and an accelerator---open to his Tandon community.

I think that a Higher Ed Institution (HEI) is a natural venue-partner for our HML prototype. If NYU-Tandon passes on this opportunity, we have---literally!---10 other HEIs in Downtown Brooklyn. Next in line would probably be CUNY NY Tech followed by LIU... (The Downtown BK Partnership has already created a working consortium of these 11 HEIs and their 60K (!!) students---another resource we WILL tap!)

In the meantime, Kurt and I are continuing our discussions around the specific common-interests we identified on 11 January. And, our HML "Asks!"

(F) This last week, I had another principal-to-principal Partner/Donor Meeting with a 3DP player AND a very rich experience with Genspace---one of their public "Entrepreneur Talks" and exchanges thereafter about mutual interests (I love this pioneering and innovative LifeSci organization!) ---

As these fertile matters develop, I'll be back to fill you in.

---LG

[End]

+++

HOWEVER, WE HAVE CHANGED THE VENUE!!!

CitySci is an innovative STEM-Ed NfP using the City as an education venue. Great folks, great ideas, great implementations.

Reason for this change?? I JUST heard from HUGE, Inc.---our prior planned Host for 26 January---that the makeover of their Meeting Spaces at 45 Main Street will not be completed on the schedule they had expected. As promised, I'll update you about our latest Health Maker Lab advances---via this page and email direct to you---prior to our Meetup next week.

Looking forward to working with You in this New Year. Come next week to help us power our HML "rocket ride" as we accelerate our progress in 2016. Come be part of something important...for You, for all our Synergists and for members of the other communities we plan to enhance! 

How? By empowering Citizen-Scientists---like You---to create healthier lifestyles, novel healthcare solutions and better patient outcomes at the local MakerRoots. (Say...THIS is part of Health Maker Lab's Mission Statement...!)


LAND

[The following was published here 3 December 2015.] 

Okay, Would-Be Synergist! Yep, I'm addressing those of you---among our 200 members---who have yet to get personally involved since you "signed up" here with "HCx3DP Meetup NY." 

This is still our official name...even though we've invested the last seven or eight months in a key, innovative subset of "HCx3DP..." That is "Health Maker Lab"---HML, for short.

Bear with me! In this update, I'm going to present additional (compelling!!) reasons for you to commit more of your time and attention to HML. I think in many cases, your free-will commitment likely comes down---in the main---to the appeal of our evolving strategies. And, how---despite this world full of so much choice---they complement your own interests .

Fair enough. Since some of you joined our Meetup Community, we HAVE changed our targets and readjusted our focus. Health Maker Lab is BOTH broader and narrower than HCx3DP. 

Broader in that we've expanded "3DP" to Digital Fabrication---or, DigiFab. You know as well as I that tech of every kind is evolving at lightning speed. 3D Printing is an important subset of DigiFab---especially when applied to Healthcare solutions. BUT, there are effective ways and means beyond 3DP to deliver those novel and necessary answers. Especially if we're thinking "Big Tent."

Narrower in that we've drilling down to determine the most effective of our ultimate HML solutions. Those solutions that will best meet the needs of specific patient, client or recipient communities for improved health---in a larger compass of that phrase. From our HML Community to the larger local community by narrowing our "envisioning" to integrate appropriate solutions. Even if they are NOT the traditional modes of "modern" medicine.

Big Tent---

Now---as this post's title suggests---our HML operational strategy includes putting up a Big Tent and inviting disparate interests (yours!) to enter in expectation and join in our convocation successfully. At this point, we will be hard put to keep our internal HML Action Centers to eight or 10. And, to address the needs of "only" five or six external neighborhood partner or player populations. 

Internally, diverse Action Centers will promote the cross-pollination of new and novel ideas. Leading to what we hope are effective hybrid solutions in Healthcare. 

Externally, serving the varied needs of sometimes competing neighborhood interest groups and organizations ("Hood Hubs!") WILL add to the complexity of our interfaces, relationships and connections. Human interactions ARE usually "messy." (As Miss Frizzle of "The Magic School Bus" admonishes those who would produce scientific creativity: "Take chances; make mistakes; get messy.") We will have to inform our out-facing perspectives with common-good POVs commonly shared.

GeoPrint---

Our HML "action footprint" on the maps of our overlapping communities---our GeoPrint---are likely to be rather fluid. Especially to start. The interests of our HML Community, donors and partners and Healthcare recipients will ensure some curious GeoPrint "gerrymandering." At least until we can rationalize our efforts---from (eventually) adequate resources.

Our startup GeoPrint will (likely!) center in Brooklyn---the "Techreative" Borough. Our initial home-base will (likely!) reside in the Brooklyn Tech Triangle (BTT). That's DUMBO (the City's official "Digital District"), the Brooklyn Navy Yard (335 tech-driven startups and ramp-ups) and Downtown Brooklyn (14 higher ed institutions and 60K students). A rich stew of assets that will help us to launch successfully. (I've lived and worked in Brooklyn for over 35 years and I can vouch for its base of resources---in our pursuit of a new kind of Health.) 

From the BTT, we'll (likely!) spread in Brownstone and Riparian (East River) BK and east into UltraUrban East New York and Brownsville. Neighborhoods of high health needs. NYC enjoys 55 major Healthcare facilities. The self-selected among these will act as our first Hood Hubs among equals. We are---after all---focused on Health and hospitals strive to deliver that uncommon commodity.

Donors and partners---action resources---may drive the expansion of our GeoPrint in unpredictable directions. It is possible that interested players in northern New Jersey could influence our development there---before, say, The Bronx or Staten Island. Certainly, the TriState Region is a natural GeoPrint extension for HML. After that...the world?!!

Viral Ecosystem---

Health Maker Lab is intent on prototyping its inspirations, ideas and innovations in an initial "sandbox" location. We'll play with the combinations that fascinate and foster the most promising solutions to diverse needs. The most  certain possibilities are the certainty of the unexpected. 

As an antidote to negative results, we will call on our Advisory Council (eventually 15 in number) of proven players. These advisors---the bases for our Action Centers---will keep us progressing appropriately to a stable ecosystem at our first HML location.

At that breakout point, we envision a kind of viral HML "reproduction" regimen will commence. Successful ways and means, models and modes and---most importantly---trained and experienced cadre will empower rapid growth (likely?) within New York City.

+++

These expectations will indeed require good people to achieve. Thus, we need YOU to become an active Synergist for Health Maker Lab success. Get excited; get psyched; get into action!

+++

Please join-in our 15 December Meetup (RSVP and contribute here). Learn more about our Health Maker Lab strategic overview in person. Come find your personal reason(s) to become an active member of our Community. Move us ahead...

Best!

LAND, Organizer       
HCx3DP Meetup NY   
& Founder, Health Maker Lab

+++


[The following was published here 2 December 2015.] 

HUZZAH!

Health Maker Lab is now a New York State Nonprofit corporation. Yowza!!!

+++

In transitioning into a Not-for-Profit (NfP), we'll be picking up our development tempo...and, therefore, our need for "in-kind," hands-on, volunteer support. 

Want to join-in the innovation on our HealthMaker "groundfloor?!" Got WordPress chops? (We're building a new HML Web site.) QuickBooks skills? (We need bookkeeping.) Media cred? (We're hot to tell the world---and all those potential donors out there---of the Healthcare solutions our Citizen Scientists will be creating...) 

During our early going here, we're likely to need many different skill sets. If you're intent on helping, we're intent on having your good assistance. Reach out and tell us what you can---and/or want to---do...

+++

Today, we received email notification of our new "NfP" status. (According to Albany, our "Exist Date" is 19 November 2015. But, it took the Department of State nearly two more weeks to let us know...hey, we're grateful it was that quick!)

I'd like to publicly thank our Brooklyn Law School (BLS) Legal-Intern Team---ably led by Dominika Wilk---for their professional, pro bono work on HML's behalf in this NfP incorporation effort. These graduate law students work for the Community Development Clinic of BLS' CUBE (Center for Urban Business Entrepreneurship) under the Directorship of Professor David Reiss.

Our next steps in this NfP process include infrastructure-building efforts---like By-Law customization and constitution of a Board of Directors and our "Advisory Council." This latter will be an official structuring of our current informal advisory team. 

Further steps will include pursuit of our status as a 501(c)(3) Nonprofit via an application to the IRS. (This is the coveted class that enables donors to HML to take tax advantage of their donations.) Where NYState process took weeks, the IRS is likely to take months. 

Fortunately, my Congresswoman Nydia Velazquez is the Ranking Democratic Member of the Small Business Committee of the House of Representatives. I've recently participated in a roundtable on Federal "grantsmanship" organized by Ms. Velazquez. So, her local staff has already promised proactive "constituent services" in expediting our IRS NfP petition. 

In the meantime, HML will nonetheless be able to legally accept NfP donations. Future IRS validation will enable retroactive donation-deductions by our givers.

Please come out to our 15 December Meetup (RSVP and contribute here). Come learn more---about what and when and where and how we're doing---in person. Come get excited!!

Best!

LAND, Organizer      
HCx3DP Meetup NY  
& Founder, Health Maker Lab

+++


[The following was published here 1 December 2015.]


Dear Synergist!

In the run-up to our 15 December Meetup, I will continue to showcase our Health Maker Lab (HML) evolutions for your understanding and benefit. 

To that end, here is our latest HML Mission Statement, Revision #4. (Certainly, with more Revs to come.) Let us have your input, please!

We submitted our Nonprofit application to New York State at the start of November. We expect to receive the State's approval this month.

+++

Mission Statement (Revision #4):

Short Form

Health Maker Lab empowers New York City Citizen-Scientists to create healthier lifestyles, novel Healthcare solutions and better patient outcomes at their community MakerRoots---via effective, open-source tech and co-located, commingled and complementary bio/med/tech disciplines in co-tenanted LifeSciences focused, outfitted and supported Maker Spaces.

Long Form

Health Maker Lab (HML) empowers New York City Citizen-Scientists to create healthier lifestyles, novel Healthcare solutions and better patient outcomes at their community MakerRoots---via effective, open-source tech and co-located, commingled and complementary bio/med/tech disciplines in a co-tenanted LifeSciences focused, outfitted and supported Maker Spaces.

We will take a "Big Tent" approach to nurturing creativity by cross-breeding new development-models across and among Health-focused sectors. This includes the integration of HML-based Action Centers---a community of affiliations that support multi-discipline, multi-tenant, multi-service-provisioned Life Makers to interact successfully.

To begin fostering superior healthy life-styles and patient out-comes, we will establish our prototype HML in "Techreative" Brooklyn. To assure success and sustainability at our ultra-urban, neighborhood level, we will employ appropriate, open-source technology and new modes of Life Making. These latter include Health Making, Bio/Med Tech, LifeScience Entrepreneurship and Healthcare-Job Generation.

Our HML solution drivers will include:

(1) the Maker Movement ethos (DIY, DIT & DID {Do It at a Distance});

(2) positive, technology-driven disrupting and democratizing ("DisDem") today's and tomorrow's Healthcare;

(3) regular community convocations ("ComCon") of interests via physical affiliation and online connection; and

(4) new modes of tech education and enablement (e.g., hyper-search, tactile or project-based learning, just-in-time education and bespoke bootcamps).

HML seeks to assure effective integration with---and service to---its home neighborhood. To that end, we will closely collaborate with key community players and institutions---while remaining independent: physically, operationally and psychologically. These local, HML "anchor/partners" will include:

(A) healthcare facilities,

(B) economic development organizations,

(C) educational institutions,

(D) local government offices and

(E) faith-based congregations.

Going forward, Health Maker Lab will strive to build a network of interconnected Labs throughout the Five Boroughs---on the way to extending our Health Maker Lab community-system to the Tri-State Region.

Copyright Land Grant 2015.

+++

As we add new updates to our Event Page description, we will leave previous "posts"---for your review---serially in place below each new entry.

Best!

LAND, Organizer     
HCx3DP Meetup NY 
& Founder, Health Maker Lab

+++

results.description:
OCaml's powerful object system is notoriously unused by most OCaml programmers. In this talk, we'll hear from a LISP expert about some advanced uses of objects and discuss how to best support the features in OCaml.


Talk:


We first briefly consider metaprogramming and describe what macros are, how they work, how to write them correctly and when to use them.

Metaclasses are described next along with what they are used for and can accomplish. A specific use-case will be examined in depth. This is done in the context of the Common Lisp Object System (CLOS). We also examine true multiple inheritance and how it affects method dispatching and method combination.

The remainder of the talk focuses on Metaobject protocols and describes the problems that MOPs were designed to solve. We look at how to design and implement a metaobject protocol for CLOS and specifically examine code that implements the 'defclass' macro which is CLOS's class definition mechanism. We then extend the implementation to support metaobject protocol functionality.

No prior knowledge of Lisp or CLOS will be assumed and the presentation is expected to be self-contained.

The material covered in this talk will mostly be drawn from the following three books: "On Lisp" by Paul Graham, "Common Lisp the Language" by Guy Steele and  The "Art of the Metaobject Protocol" by Gregor Kiczales, Jim des Rivieres and Daniel G. Bobrow.

Speaker: Pierre de Lacaze has over 20 years experience with Lisp and AI based technologies. He holds a Bachelor of Science in Applied Mathematics and Computer Science and a Master’s Degree in Computer Science. He is the President of LispNYC and is also a Senior Developer at Shareablee.

Lightning Talks: Please let me know if you want to give a 3 minute talk, by email or in person a few minutes before we start.

Food and venue kindly provided by our sponsor, Jane Street.

As always, we'll walk over to one of the bars on Stone Street after the talk.
results.name: Metaclasses and Metaobject Protocols

results.description:
Six people will teach us something awesome about chrome developer tools and tips. If you have an idea and you'd like to present, let us know here. 


Agenda

• 6:30pm - 6:45pm: meet and greet

• 6:45pm - 7:45pm: presentations

• 7:45pm - 8:15pm: meet and greet


• 8:15pm: drinks nearby (TBD)


Presentations

- The console - Whitney Levine

- Performance and Profiling - by Chris Kim

- Device targeting - Sarah Ashraf

- Quick random tricks - Jason Laster

- let us know here

Who should come?

The meetup is open to any engineer who is still learning (to us, that means every engineer). We ask that the speakers target their talks for the following background...

If I'm teaching at this meetup, what should I do?

Talks are 10 minutes total including questions. This usually means preparing 5 minutes of content and taking 5 minutes of questions.

To help teachers hone their clarity, we encourage the audience to ask questions during the talks. For now, we’re limiting questions to one question per audience member to keep things moving.

A few other guidelines:

• Make sure you target the topic of the meetup

• Your talk should target teaching engineers something that they can use soon - likely immediately. That means most talks should avoid non-free or and non-open-source software.


• Your talk should be broadly applicable. This means you should avoid avoid company pitches.


• Please practice your presentation all the way through at least once!

Who should I target my talk toward?

We generally expect engineers at all experience levels to be at the meetup, but feel free to make the following assumptions:

• Members have used a scripting language (ex: Ruby, Python, PHP, Javascript). Don’t assume people have experience with other languages - it’s fine to present in them, but you may need to be ready to answer a few more questions.

• Members have some experience with a web framework.

• Members have basic knowledge of the command line.

• Members have used a version control system.

Who should not come?

We focus on teaching, learning, and technology, not recruiting. If your primary goal is to recruit engineers, there are other places to go.
results.name: Teach Us Something Technical: Chrome Developer Tools

Announcing a joint meetup between Agile Experience Design and Balanced Team NYC! Have you ever been the designer who spent days designing an interaction only to find out it couldn't be built? Or the engineer blocked on shipping a feature because you were waiting on Design to "figure it out"? A PM taking all the stress on your shoulders, trying to bridge the divide? It's time to take down those silo walls! Two balanced teams will offer their lessons learned – their successes, their failures, and the key tactics they used to stay aligned as a team and continuously learn from each other, as well as their users.

Presenters

Josh Franklin, Alex Basson, and Jim Thomson – a designer, an engineer, and a PM from Pivotal Labs will share their experience building the Small Token iOS app with Pivotal Labs.

Brooke Kao, Michael Morrissey and Emerson Taymor - a designer, engineer and product strategist from Philosophie will share their experience iterating, shipping and testing quickly to launch PricewaterhouseCoopers first consumer mobile app. Agenda:

6:30 to 7:00pm - Space opens, Meet & Greet

7:00 - 8:30 - Presentation and Discussion
results.name: Balanced Teams in Practice: True Tales of Breaking Down Silos and Smashing Walls

results.description:
To RSVP fill out the form here --->>> http://eepurl.com/btziMb

Learn How to Get out of the Rat Race in Real Life!

Cashflow 101 is a fun way to learn the basic concepts of Real estate Investing. Your objective throughout the night will be to get out of the rat race and into the fast track! In other words you have to find a way to get out of that 9-5 and step into the life you always wanted to live, the strategies learned in the game can be applied in real life! We're going to show you how me and my team play cashflow in real life and how we help people implement these strategies to get out of the rat race.

How do you get out of the race race you ask?

Your total monthly passive income has to be higher than your total monthly expenses, you're going to learn the importance of acquiring assets vs stacking up liabilities and how you will be able to use your money wisely instead of just using it to pay bills. We're going to show you practical strategies you can use in your life today that will change your perspective about investing and we will shatter some of the myths people have about money.

Cashflow 101 is an educational tool in board game format which aims to teach the players concepts of investing by having their money work for them in a risk free setting (play money) while simultaneously increasing financial literacy and stressing the imperative nature of accountability.


If you have ever played monopoly this game is like monopoly on steroids!  If you're serious about learning and expanding your knowledge about investing in real estate DON'T MISS THIS EVENT!

To RSVP fill out the form here --->>> http://eepurl.com/btziMb
results.name: Cashflow 101- learn how to get out of the rat race in real life!

results.description:
Join us for Scrabble every Wednesday.  The first people usually arrive between 5:00 and 5:30, and the last people leave around 10:00.  Come any time.

We tend to play two-person games.  It's a friendly, low-key game with a range of skill levels.  Whatever people agree on in terms of dictionaries, challenges, and anything else is fine.  The main objective is to have fun.

Panera in Wayne is on Route 23 southbound, in the Brentwood Plaza (second driveway south of Ratzer Road).
results.name: Scrabble
we'll be dancing to different styles of music learning all the basics.

group.name: Long Beach Bellydance For Fun and Fitness Meetup

results.description:
Hey Everyone!

Thanks for coming out to the last meetup, it was a lot of fun and it was great to see you all there! This is the fastest turnaround we've had for subsequent meetups but I'm really excited to announce Shawn Milochik as a guest speaker! While the focus will be covering what's new in Go 1.6, we'll also have a networking time after the talk where you can get to know others and just hang out!

Join other Central Jersey gophers in celebrating the upcoming release of Go 1.6. The actual release date is yet to be announced, but the global Go community is organizing release parties on February 17th to celebrate and educate.

Guest speaker Shawn Milochik will be presenting a slide deck provided by the Go community detailing all the exciting news about Go 1.6, as well as taking questions and possibly some A/B demoes comparing Go 1.5 and 1.6. 

More info about the global release party is available here: https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/Go-1.6-release-party

Food and beverages will be sponsored by TelTech as always!
results.how_to_find_us: When you come to our building, just come to the side door underneath the awning and ring the bell!
results.name: Go 1.6 release party and more at TelTech!

results.description:
Learn how to create a healthy lifestyle with Essential Oils!

During this free introductory workshop you will experience the many uses of therapeutic grade Young Living Essential Oils. Meet like-minded friends and discover: 


• oils to support  healthy immune function and emotional well-being for children and adults 

• oils to aid in weight loss

• oils to promote restful sleep 

• oils to support mood by uplifting and encouraging positive energy

• oils that support digestion 

• oils to help restore mental alertness and focus for homework

• oils that promote skin and joint health for all ages

• oils to enhance athletic performance and endurance for school sports and activities 

• various ways to use essential oils for the whole family - even pets 

• ways to eliminate toxic chemicals from your home 

As a special treat be sure to take a few minutes to lie down in our Aroma Dome! Ahhh... bliss.....:)
results.how_to_find_us: Exit 135 off the Parkway - free parking in the back.
results.name: Essential Oils Wellness Workshop

results.description: We have a couple of interesting things on the program - Bill Fagnant will give a talk on restoring (and using) vintage woodworking machinery, I will be demonstrating a technique for producing a limed Oak finish, and I'm also working on getting another presenter that I'm sure you will all enjoy.
results.name: Share you knowledge of Vintage Woodworking Machinery with Bill Fagnant

results.description:
Mindful Astoria: Wednesday Meditation Gathering

Join us on Wednesday nights for meditation and conversation about mindfulness. Learn how to bring mindfulness into daily life, and how to establish, maintain, and deepen a personal mindfulness practice.

Each class will consist of instruction in different forms of mindfulness meditation, and time for group discussion and connecting with the community. Depending on the week, the teacher may give a talk or share a reading about a related topic.

Check out our group guidelines.

Teacher for this night's gathering: Emily Herzlin 

Emily is a writer, editor, and teacher. She has taught creative writing and mindfulness meditation at Columbia University, The Interdependence Project, Adelphi University, GreenspaceNYC, and Mission to (dit)Mars. Emily has been practicing mindfulness meditation for ten years, and trained in Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) through the Center for Mindfulness at UMass Medical School. She is also a graduate of the Yearlong Immersion and Teacher Training program at the Interdependence Project, where she currently teaches MBSR. 

Mindful Astoria

Every Wednesday, 7-8:30pm at the Astoria First Presbyterian Church.

All classes are drop-in, but RSVP. $5-$10 at the door to cover meetup dues and support the teachers and the Astoria Presbyterian Church. *Note that no one will be turned away for lack of funds. If you cannot afford the suggested donation, please give what you are able.

Email any questions to Emily Herzlin at [masked].

Looking forward to deepening practice and strengthening mindful community with you all!
results.how_to_find_us: The church is located at 23-35 Broadway, between Crescent St. and 23rd St. It is on the north side of Broadway, just past Trade Fair and Synergy Fitness. There is an awning over the front door. The church shares the space with Art House Astoria.
results.name: Mindful Astoria: Wednesday Meditation Gathering

results.description:
Interested in out-of-body experiences and psychic experiences? Your welcome to join us at one of free public seminars!

Have you ever had a vivid flying dream? How about the sensation of floating while falling asleep or meditating? How about the perception of “dropping” back into your body just before waking up? If so it may be possible that you have experienced what is called an out-of-body experience. It has sometimes been known in various spiritual traditions and schools of thought in history, as “astral projection” or “soul travel”.

Despite being considered by many to be a strange or obscure topic, the experience has been reported for thousands of years by people all over the world, often mixed up with dreams. Throughout history people have reported “otherworldly” journeys and spiritual experiences into other dimensions in a variety of settings - during spiritual practices (i.e meditation, prayer, etc), near-death, during sleep or spontaneously during the day. What is interesting is that unbeknownst to most of the public, is that the out-of-body experience is a powerful tool for self-transformation, self-discovery and wellness and can be willfully induced, developed, controlled and utilized to greatly benefit yourself and others. The experience is much like the altered states of consciousness that shamans and medicine men in history used to connect with the psychic world, obtain knowledge, heal others, etc.

This short seminar is offered freely to the public and will provide you with cutting edge information on out-of-body experiences (i.e. astral projection, soul travel, etc), subtle energy, non-physical dimensions and related topics. Cutting through misconceptions and misinformation about the topic, you will learn about the latest research on these experiences, including their benefits (see below) and – unbeknownst to most of us – how they already affect our daily life yet have huge implications about who you are and your life purpose.
Some of the benefits of the out-of-body experience are:

• Understanding non-physical dimensions or realities
• Direct contact with spirit guides
• Development of psychic abilities
• Losing the fear of death
• Getting information about your life purpose
• Using OBEs as a tool to assist or heal others
• Psychic awareness and protection
• Development of universalism and fraternity

In addition to these benefits, these additional fascinating topics will be discussed at the lecture:

• Our multidimensional nature
• How the OBE experience (i.e astral projection, etc) works
• How an OBE is experienced first hand
• Astral projection tips, benefits & utilities
• How to use the OBE to discover our life purpose
• Psychic abilities related to the OBE
• Our multiple subtle bodies and their function
• What current research tells us about the OBE
• Overview of easy out-of-body experience techniques
• Non physical dimensions
• What happens psychically at night
• Information about IAC’s OBE and psychic training programs
• Answers to questions you have about these topics or your experiences

Is this lecture right for you?

This lecture is packed with fascinating information and is interesting to both those new to the topic, or those already quite knowledgeable about it. Whether you’re just curious about the topic, want to ask about an experience you had, or what to go deeper, this lecture is for you. It is well suited for anyone planning on further study but still looking for a rational, integrated overview of these frequently misunderstood topics.

If you are interested in IAC’s other programs, note that this free lecture is an ideal (although optional) starting point for people interested in taking IAC’s other courses. It allows would-be students to make a personal connection with our instructors and team, obtaining confidence in our knowledge, approach, and framework. This lecture also introduces our organization, and gives an overview of our curriculum, programs, and publications. Hence it is a great opportunity to ask an instructor about IAC's main OBE training course, the award-winning Consciousness Development Program (CDP), which we offer regularly in New York.

Who teaches this free lecture? 

It is taught by one of IAC’s senior faculty members, depending on who’s available. IAC’s faculty members have years of experience and training in spirituality and consciousness studies, including out-of-body experiences and psychic phenomena. IAC is an educational and research centered organization in the area of consciousness studies, human potential and psychic development, and has offices in over 12 countries worldwide.

How do I attend?

Confirm via meetup that you're attending or email us to register at newyork (-at-) iacworld.org
results.how_to_find_us: 59th and Lex subway is closest. The entrance to our building is under the palace restaurant awning near the corner of 57th and Lex.
results.name: Free Seminar on Out-of-Body Experiences and Consciousness Studies

results.description:
Have you ever tried Salsa? How about CUBAN salsa? Now is your chance to learn this exciting and fun dance! On Wednesday, February 3rd, we are offering a Cuban-style Salsa TOTAL BEGINNER introduction class! The class will start its curriculum from scratch, will be in a dance studio, and will be kept comfortably small to facilitate learning, so IT DOESN’T MATTER IF YOU HAVE NEVER DANCED! Also, having a partner is not required as we constantly rotate during the class. This format gives you the opportunity to practice your steps with various partners and prepares you for the social dance scene in a safe and pressure-free environment!

The teachers, a male and female, teach progressive levels of Cuban Salsa Partner work, also known as Casino and Rueda de Casino - an interactive group dance where there are constant partner exchanges with fun patterns executed in unison!

The February session of Cuban Salsa:

Wednesdays (February 3rd - 24th):

7:00-8:30pm Beginner Cuban Salsa & Rueda de Casino  - Level 1

This class is for absolute beginners with little to no dance experience and will allow you to develop a strong foundation in Cuban Salsa in an extremely fun, stress-free atmosphere. In each 90-minute class of the four week series, students focus on developing dance fundamentals including rhythm, coordination, balance, and the specific technical aspects of Cuban Salsa, including basic steps and turn patterns, partnering technique, and the fundamental motions of Casino and Rueda de Casino. Students will also learn social dancing etiquette, floorcraft, and partner <a>safety in</a> an extremely warm, relaxed, social and fun environment. If you can walk, you can do this, so let your friends with two left feet know!

PRICE
-For First Time members & their guests, 1st Class: ONLY $10, 50% OFF!!!
Normally $20 Drop-In!
-Level 1 full month package of 4 Classes: ONLY $60
that's 4 classes (6 hours total) for the price of 3!!!

LOCATION
Adelante Studios
25 West 31st Street between Broadway & 5th Avenue
2nd Floor - Grand Ballroom (3,000 sq ft!)

Nearby Subways: 34th St Station on B, D, F, M, N, Q, R, & PATH trains.
*Can't find us? Call[masked] and we'll point you in the right direction.

All classes are taught by both a male, Chris, and female, Nayelli, so women can easily follow another woman while men are following a man at the same time! They have over 16-years of training, teaching, performing, and traveling to Cuba to collaborate with the very best in the Salsa world. Feel free to contact them at any time for additional info or if you have any questions.

Chris: [masked] /[masked]

Video link of our group doing Rueda de Casino
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UK02-HTye7k
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cINgMRwiL7Q

For those with previous experience dancing Casino, we offer a Level 2/Intermediate class immediately following Level 1 on Wednesdays at 8:30pm.

Intermediate - Level 2

Wednesdays (February 3rd - 24th):

8:30 - 10:00pm Intermediate Cuban Salsa & Rueda de Casino - Level 2

This progressive, 90-min class is geared for those that have danced Cuban Salsa and/or Rueda before and allows you to further solidify, fine-tune, and expand upon the basics covered in Level 1. Here is your opportunity to refresh all of the beginning motions at a pace that is comfortable for you while further building a solid foundation in this exciting, interactive, and fun dance. This high-energy class focuses on combinations, leading and following technique, group moves, styling, body motion, and fun salsa suelta footwork. By the end of the 8-week sequence, you will have all the tools necessary to get out on the dance floor and be fun, fluid, and spontaneous with everything you've learned. *For those that register for Level 2, Level 1 is included as extra practice, free of charge, in your monthly package.*

Sample Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cINgMRwiL7Q

***************************************************

We also offer classes at the advanced level on Tuesdays (February 2nd) at Adelante Studios.  Here's the info -

7:00 - 8:30pm Intermediate-transition-to-Advanced Cuban Salsa & Rueda de Casino - Level 3

This progressive series serves as a bridge class for intermediate dancers who have already completed Level 2 and are ready to step up their game. The focus is on technique, as we will provide you with insights on what advanced dancers are constantly attending to while engaging with their partner. Each 90-minute session is broken down into 3 parts - Suelta (Footwork & Movement), Casino (One-on-One Partnering), and Rueda - all danced to rhythmically dense Timba. By the end of this 8-week series, you will be equipped with all the necessary tools to make a seamless transition into the advanced level. *For those that register for Level 3, Levels 1 & 2 are included as extra practice, free of charge, in your monthly package.*

Sample Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSHUoyjfxlA

Location:

Adelante Studios
25 W 31st Street between Broadway and 5th Avenue
2nd Floor
Grand Ballroom

Nearby Subways: 34th St Station on B, D, F, M, N, Q, R, & PATH trains.

*Can't find our room? Call[masked] and we'll point you in the right direction.
results.how_to_find_us: Take elevators to the 2nd Floor & make a left. We have the entire studio loft space, complete with brand new, clean rooms, hardwood floors, mirrors, 12’ ceiling, A/C, & sound system.
results.name: Cuban Salsa & Rueda de Casino Classes!

results.description:
Many entrepreneurs love to watch Shark Tank on TV to see the rich Sharks pound away at the ideas of various business founders. What wisdom does the Shark Tank impart? Some of the best shows are the follow ups where businesses the Sharks rejected go on to success anyway. Let's get together to watch some episodes over some light snacks and discuss the show afterwards.

And do you know who the MegaShark is that wins every single episode with every single deal?


Note that reception is closed after 5pm. When you get off the elevator please look for the Small Business sign and follow the instructions (either to wait in the waiting area, call, or proceed to a meeting room)
results.name: Shark Tank Showdown!!!

results.description:
Come make ecstatic, spontaneous choral music with us! We gather for two hours of improvised group singing on the third Wednesday of the month.

CircleSinging is a form of facilitated Vocal Improv which could be described as “a drum circle for singers” or “improvised choral music.” During the course of the ever-changing chant, the leader develops and gives parts to a circle of singers, which in turn supports individual solos. Both participating in and witnessing the creation of the music that emerges is an exhilarating and joyful experience.

Please note: Bringing water to drink is recommended but CAP21 also sells water bottles at the front desk.

Admission is $15 - $30 sliding scale. Please be generous to the extent you can afford. (No one will be turned away for lack of funds.) For more information, please contact Ben at[masked]-8918.
results.name: February CircleSing!

Our last Battle Of The Sexes Trivia was our biggest one yet!

results.description:
If you've not come to one of our meetups before, it's a group of fun nerdy gays playing casual games of MtG. It's a great place to learn and have fun in a low pressure friendly setting. Whether you're a regular tournament player or a first-timer, you'll fit right in.

As Oath of the Gatewatch has given us tons of new cards that are meant for two-headed giant, we're going to play it again this time. You'll be paired up with a partner randomly after you arrive. Each of you will play separately but will share a combined 40 life total. Attacks will be free-for-all. If there's an odd number, one player will get to play two decks.

Again, everyone is welcome. If you've got an old deck laying around or you just bought your first booster pack yesterday, you're still welcome. We're here to play socially and have fun. The following cards are banned:

In addition to the talk, by attending this event you will be entered into a raffle for a free ticket to the Kanban Leadership Retreat! Also, every attendee will receive a free eBook of the Essential Kanban Condensed Guide!

Description: 


Many companies think they're "doing Agile" once their developers start working in sprints. But if all of the phases of the work are completed in big batches, companies don't get to take advantage of all of the benefits. 

Learn how a Cisco internal startup used minimally marketable features to streamline the flow of work from end-to-end and to the customer in Robert Frohman's talk, "Starving the Engine: How to Fuel a High-Performing Agile Organization".

Presenter: Robert Frohman is project manager, agile coach, and developer on Project Lockhart, a Cisco internal startup.  He has over 20 years of experience as a software developer, engineering leader, and agile consultant, focusing most recently on agile transformations.  Rob holds a Master of Science in Engineering Management from Tufts University and a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering from the University of New Hampshire.  Rob can also be found hiking and skiing in the mountains of New Hampshire and Colorado.


Location: Spotify is on 45 W. 18th Street. That's between 6th and 5th avenues, above the Bed Bath and Beyond. They're up on the 7th floor.
results.how_to_find_us: Between 6th and 5th avenues, above the Bed Bath and Beyond. Spotify is up on the 7th floor.
results.name: Minimally Marketable Features: Improving End-to-end Product Flow + Raffle!

results.description:
What is all this? Here's the short version:

Geeks Who Drink is a homegrown Pub Trivia Quiz modeled after those in Ireland and the UK.

Our quizzes cover everything from celebrities in trouble to wordplay to bad television. You can get a feel for the questions we ask by playing a sample round here.

Each quiz has two audio rounds:  a "Name that Tune” style round, and another round comprised of soundbites from movies and TV.

Play in teams of up to six or by yourself if you're some kind of savant.

If you want to play but don’t have a team, come anyway. We can usually get single players recruited onto an existing team.  

Winning teams gets street cred, bar cash and other prizes depending on the venue. Bonus Questions for free pints are sprinkled throughout the quiz.

You don’t have to be a trivia God to enjoy the quiz. Since you’re playing on a team, the collective knowledge base makes for more fun, less pressure. It’s not final friggin' Jeopardy.

http://www.geekswhodrink.com/venue?id=611057


P.S> - Limit 6 people per team. Let's get together and win that car.
results.how_to_find_us: Please check Comments
results.name: Geeks Who Drink Trivia Night @ Stone Creek Bar & Lounge!

results.description:
Truth is at best partial, at worst error. We are at best explorers, at worst believers. If we desire to fully grow we must keep exploring. . . Welcome Explorers! (And curious believers too!)

This is a group for exploring and testing each other's new ideas, and for the potential of creating even more together!

As a starting point we'll discuss the possibility of:

A natural morality based on our passion's values;

A politics that roots out resentment so we can enjoy

a unified diversity;

And a culture of 7 billion honest individuals---

with not one truth!

 

This morality, politics, and culture have one goal: That we each flourish--that we each fully bloom into all that we are--together.

 

Can it happen? Should it happen? What do you propose? Let's talk about it!

 

 

Note: Ripple Effect Photo by Segiu Bacioiu.

results.description:
Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

6-7 pm - Show up early, stake out a spot and either socialize or get a jump on writing.
7:00 - Start. Introductions, and we'll share what we're working on
7:05 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!
8:05- Brief follow up. People are encouraged to share experiences & ideas, network or take off as they like. Feel free to keep writing if you've got the momentum going!

If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. It may just be "pipe-cleaning" for now, but you'll feel better showing up at the page. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: David Rubenstein Atrium, 62nd and Broadway.

SOME TIPS:

Please, come on time! If you come late, we will have already started.
Bring headphones if you don't want outside noise distraction.

Please RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change. We have had far too many no-shows.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.
results.name: NYC Shut Up & Write Meetup! - Columbus Circle

results.description:
ICELAND: Northern Lights Group Trip

CLICK HERE to book your spot.

The wait is over.  Hunt for the Northern Lights on this group trip to Iceland!  Join your fellow travel club members from all over February 17 - 21, 2016 on this exciting group tour to Iceland! 

NASA recently predicted that we are in the peak years of an 11 year cycle for the Northern Lights.  So that we don't have to wait another 11 years for them to max out again, we're going hunting for the Northern Lights this February in one of the world's best destinations, Iceland!  Join this group tour as we seek out the Northern Lights and while there why not join the group and visit the famous Blue Lagoon spa, walk on glaciers, see the famous and spectacular waterfall of Gullfoss, watch geysers spouting, visit a volcanic national park, and so much more!  And all with a group of fun, like-minded adventurers.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Pricing and Booking:

PRICE: $899 (airfare additional)

CLICK HERE to book your spot.

NOTE: a meetup RSVP does NOT reserve your space. For prices, details and to book your space on this tour, please CLICK HERE

----------------------------------------------------------------- 

PLEASE NOTE: trips are typically 10-15 +/- people and they tend to sell out 1 - 3 months before departure, so be sure to book your space before they sell out!  These small group trips are open for anyone to join. You can sign up as a solo traveler (roommate matching is free-OR you can get your own room) OR join with a spouse, friends or other family members. All are welcome!

GET THE SCOOP! Want to see what other club members are saying? Then check out the GEC Testimonial Page.

----------------------------------------------------------------- 

Included in the awesome adventure:
* 3 star hotels
* Small group tour of Iceland
* Northern Lights tour
* Global Expeditions Club Leader
* Expert English speaking local experts for select tours
* 4 nights lodging in an excellent 3* hotel
* Breakfast daily
* Optional Blue Lagoon Hot Springs
* Optional Golden Circle Waterfall Classic Day Trip
* Optional 12 Hour South Iceland Day Trip and Northern Lights Hunt

Need help booking your airfare?  Just email me or give me a call at[masked]

Click Here For Complete Details and Booking.

Places Visited: Group Tour of Iceland, Northern Light group tour of Iceland, Reykjavik, Optional Blue Lagoon, Nesjavellir power plant, Thingvellir volcanic park, Waterfall of Gullfoss, Seljalandsfoss waterfall, Solheimajokull glacier walk (Myrdalsjokull), Reynisfjara black sand beach, Skogafoss Waterfall, pouting hot springs of Geysir and Strokkur, northern lights (weather dependent)

----------------------------------------------------------------

The Global Expeditions Club (GEC) is a group of fun-loving travelers looking for other like-minded people to travel the world with.  The travel club started 8 years ago with just a handful of meetup members, but has grown into one of the largest travel clubs in the world.

Check out the Global Expeditions Club's Testimonial Page to see what others are saying about these trips.

Of course, if you have any questions you can always contact me or one of the other organizers through meetup message or via phone at (617)[masked]

Make Friends. Travel the World.
results.name: ICELAND: Northern Lights Group Trip

results.description:
IMPORTANT NOTE: YOU MUST BUY TICKETS FOR THIS EVENT AT OUR EVENTBRITE PAGE:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/clxnyc-culture-fit-vs-culture-add-tickets-20960658895

Even if you RSVP below, please ALSO go to the eventbrite page and make a payment there. We will be checking for your eventbrite RSVP at the door.

Ticket costs will go towards beverages and appetizers.

---

CULTURE LABx is a global community of founders, designers, and practitioners who curate conversations, connect communities, and experiment with the future or work. In 2013, a group of us came together to elevate the conversation of what company culture is and isn’t. We believed it was time to move away from pizza and pingpong, and refocus on the essence of any great company—the people.

The NYC lab will run four events a year, ranging from discussions to panels to workshops. 

Winter 2016: Hiring for Cultural Fit vs. Cultural Add

Many managers believe that hiring for cultural fit is a top priority. But has the drive for cultural fit gone rogue? Has it shifted into a different kind of pursuit? Are talent managers actually hiring based on a series of values and beliefs, or just hiring based on who they’d like to hang out with? And how do you tell the difference?

According to a May 2013 article in Harvard Business Review, Creating the Best Workplace On Earth, “Achieving the full benefit of diversity means trading the comfort of being surrounded by kindred spirits for the hard work of fitting various kinds of people, work habits, and thought traditions into a vibrant culture. Managers must continually work out when to forge ahead and when to take the time to discuss and compromise.” 

We’ll hear from discussion leaders about the difference between hiring for cultural fit versus hiring for “cultural add” (meaning people who add to the current cultural mix and enhance the organization). We’ll learn how organizations are using cultural fit or add in productive ways through interviews, communication styles, and surveys.

Confirmed Discussion Leaders:

Rebekah Rombom, VP of Business Development at the Flatiron School, which provides training in mobile and web development

Allison Roarty, HR Business Partner at TwoSigma (formerly ran diversity recruiting programs at Google)

Matt LeMay is the Co-Founder of Constellate Data, a consultancy that helps organizations use data to understand people. He previously worked as Senior Product Manager at Songza (acquired by Google) and Head of Consumer Product at Bitly. Matt is also a musician, recording engineer, and author of a book about singer-songwriter Elliott Smith.

Sunil Sadasivan is the CTO at Buffer and has been thinking deeply as he's hired many new folks to their (completely distributed) team.
results.name: CLxNYC: Culture Fit vs. Culture Add

results.description:
The fee is $10 if you pay un advance and $15 at the door. 


To pay, go here:  https://www.eventbrite.com/e/wise-women-waking-tickets-21048689196 Welcome to a wonderful group of creative, passionate, and purposeful midlife women who are committed to living a life of meaning and contribution.


Please join us for a warm and stimulating gathering of inspired Wise Women as we explore questions like:
What is calling you?
How do you recognize this calling?
How far are you in your expression of it?
What is stopping you?
Who do you believe yourself to be that may be limited or not limited?
Who do you want to be or to become? 

Why is midlife (or beyond) the perfect time to recreate yourself and step into the highest expression of your soul? 
Why is this moment in history such a powerful call to be all we can be? 
How do you relate to the unknown, to being in a process of discovery?
What is it that you feel called to serve - in other people, in the world?
What do you feel most passionate about, what is your Big Why?
How can we all balance the call of our soul and the world with the practical necessities of life?
How is the world transforming and how are you a part of that, contributing to positive change?
What is your version of Heaven on Earth and how do you see yourself contributing to that? 
How can we clear the inner fears, doubts, limiting beliefs and stories we tell ourselves that keep us disempowered - so that we can be the powerful limitless beings we truly are? 
How have all the experiences of your life led up to this moment, so that you can make your contribution? 
What are the steps to becoming fully empowered women, contributing to the resurgence of the Sacred Feminine in the world? 
What is your unique role in the global transformation, that can bring you personal fulfillment while it helps others?
results.name: New York Wise Women Waking

results.description:
I am a Spanish native speaker and suggest we meet at Think Coffee to help you to improve your Spanish!

There is a maximum of 6 students per group and costs $10/person if more than 3 people come to the class and $15/person if 1 to 3 people come to the class.

My phone number is[masked] just in case you cannot find me.

Don´t sign up if you are not sure you can come.

The lesson lasts 1 hour.

Hasta pronto!

Beguinner level means: you are not able to speak without the help of the teacher, you just know really little common expresions. We will go thought the basics.

Intermediate level means: you can explain yourself with the help of the teacher, you can build up sentences but they are basic or you make mistakes on them. You have lacks of vocabulary and grammar.

Advanced level means: you are fluent in Spanish, you can explain yourself without a lof of problems. You know the vocabulary. Advanced students normally make gramatical mistakes when they talk and can forget some words, that is perfectly normal.
results.name: Spanish conversation Intermediate. $10/person if more 3people or $15/p if less

results.description:
Wall Street Share is hosting another gathering in its offices for promising private companies seeking to build new relationships and/or attain access to investors and strategic partners.  Since its inception late last year, Wall Street Share has selected 8 companies to move into its space.  We have provided such companies with many resources and access to critical relationships that they otherwise may have been unable to attain, and we have invested our own capital in some of the endeavors in our space.  

The primary purpose of our meetups is to gather new promising companies, share ideas, help connect them with others to explore synergies, and potentially provide them with valuable resources and relationships to help them get to the next level.  We have been hosting meetups in our large conference room; it's an intimate setting that has enabled all attendees to discuss their stories and needs.  Anyone is welcome to attend, so don’t feel intimidated.  It’s a very casual setting comprising entrepreneurs and companies at a wide gamut of stages in which we have stimulating discussions.

If you would like to learn more about Wall Street Share or apply for a membership, please see our website at www.wallstreetshare.com.  We look forward to seeing you next week!

To CJK Experts and Native Speakers:

We practice like this (including, but not limited to):

Session 1 (7pm-8pm): Interpretation methods practice

For example, words, phrases or sentences interpretation, target language repeating, shadowing and summarization, etc.

We set two tables to practice Chinese and Korean separately (Japanese is on hiatus due to low membership). The session is basically for intermediate & above Chinese and Korean learners.

Session 2 (8pm-9pm): Topic-based speaking practice

Summary, speak or discuss the topic you are provided or you have prepared by your target language (Chinese & Korean).

Also, everybody can move to any table as they want.

If you would like to practice English, please join our regular Saturday meetup generously hosted by Carl.

Looking forward to practicing with you all!

Organizers

Dearest Beloveds,

I am deeply honored and grateful to share this 10 month journey of The Path Of Love with each of you.

The Path of Love opens you to the energy of creation and calls to you to open your heart gateway to your eternal self so that you may begin to anchor all that you are upon the Earth in unconditional love and open embrace of your Divinity.

This is the creation dreaming path where you enter the void and begin to access your highest potential through an open heart. It is here that you begin to see all the possibilities that are open for you and know that each choice you make brings you close to your divine power.

It is a deep path of self discovery where all is illuminated and you are called to embrace and honour yourself deeply. The Path of Love is the road home to all that you are.

Much Love and Gratitude,

Julie

results.description:
We are super excited to continue our brand new format for New York Legal Hackers meetups: Jam Sessions. Legal Hackers Jam Sessions are monthly small-group working sessions that are geared to address specific problems in a quick-sprint, collaborative environment. Jam Sessions will differ from our regular panel events in two ways: (1) smaller group size, and (2) more interactivity--bring your laptops and other small computing devices. One LH member will lead each Jam Session by posing a problem, with background, relevant to the Legal Hackers community, perhaps in connection with a personal project, perhaps soliciting support for a group project. From there, we will do our best to pose a real solution to the problems presented in a 2-3 hour sprint. We will hope to continue checking in on Jam Session leaders on a regular basis to see progress with time and offer additional support.

Important things to note: Unfortunately, we will have to strictly enforce the RSVP list because space is very limited. Also, as with all our events (other than hackathons), any actual software or tangible resources should be contributed to the group on a Creative Commons or Open Source basis. 

Our second Jam Session will be led by Phil Weiss. Do I Need a License? (working title:DINAL) is an idea-stage software project to help independent creatives to determine if they need a license to use someone's IP in their own work. For this Session, we are looking for designers and coders (as always), plus folks who have expertise in the following areas and who can share non-confidential info regarding: 


• Data and Statistics with respect to the copyright decisions (particularly fair use decisions)

• Backend development

• Statistical prediction

• Copyright law


If you can meaningfully contribute anything on these fronts, we strongly encourage you to attend. RSVPs will be honored on a first-come, first-serve basis--please only RSVP if you definitely plan to attend.


Until then, Rock On!
results.name: Jam Session v.002: DINAL?

results.description:
NYC-ADV'ers, temps are sub zero and we're all just staring longingly at our bikes. That said, your loving founders have organized a happy hour so everyone can get together, meet, plan future rides, imbibe, and mingle. 

Our friends at Givers and Takers have been kind enough to play host. Not only that, they've offered happy hour pricing throughout the event. According to the interwebs, Givers and Takers is a "mellow haunt that serves cocktails, brews & wines amid exposed brick walls & an old-school feel". We just think it's a rad bar, run by rad people. Not to mention it's a block down from 718 Cyclery, our home base. 

As referenced above, there will be drink specials for NYC-ADV members. Also, expect occasional give-aways from group sponsors. If all goes well, we will extend indefinitely every 1st and 3rd Wednesday of the month. This will give members a recurring opportunity to hang with like-minded bicycle enthusiasts, tourers, adventurers, and travelers. 

Come one, come all... let's meetup!

results.description:
You're invited to join us for this weekly opportunity to sharpen your drawing skills! This session is open to sketchers of all levels.

What makes our sessions different? 

• We start on time in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• We have coffee and cookies at the long break. 

• We finish on time so you can be headed home at 9:00 p.m sharp! 

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)


• This is a two hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  

• We start with short 2 minute poses and work up to a 20 minute pose by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 


• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon
