results.description:
Circling is an interpersonal meditation that creates connection to yourself and others through sharing authentically in the present moment and exploring the beautiful and multi-faceted dimensions of the human experience.

It can lead to profound connection, intimacy, insight and trust in life. It's part communication practice, and brings tools to communicate with empathy and honesty...and part spiritual practice, inviting participants to bring a higher level of awareness and embodied trust with the present moment. It looks like a group of people focusing their attention on one person with the intention of curiously being with and discovering another person for who they are...welcoming and celebrating wherever that person is at...and sharing what it's like to be in connection with him or her.


People who circle are left with a sense of community, openness, intimacy, self expression, and the capacity to connect more deeply with others.

Circling embraces the "dark" and "light" of the human experience, yin and yang, trusting people for where they are at and gives permission to bring the authentic expression of both.


Agreements will be gone over to ensure a strong container where people honor themselves and others.

Cost is $25.

Please arrive no later than 7:20 to settle in and be prepared to start at 7:30.
results.name: Introduction to Circling Night

results.description:
“J is a snarling, effervescent, and ambitious philosophical work of fiction that poses unsettling questions about our sense of history, and our self-satisfied orthodoxies. Jacobson’s triumph is to craft a novel that is poignant as well as troubling from the debris.” —Independent (UK)

Man Booker Prize–winner Howard Jacobson’s brilliant and profound new novel, J, “invites comparison with George Orwell’s 1984 and Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World” (Sunday Times, London). Set in a world where collective memory has vanished and the past is a dangerous country, not to be talked about or visited, J is a boldly inventive love story, both tender and terrifying.

Kevern Cohen doesn’t know why his father always drew two fingers across his lips when he said a word starting with a J. It wasn’t then, and isn’t now, the time or place to be asking questions. When the extravagantly beautiful Ailinn Solomons arrives in his village by a sea that laps no other shore, Kevern is instantly drawn to her. Although mistrustful by nature, the two become linked as if they were meant for each other. Together, they form a refuge from the commonplace brutality that is the legacy of a historic catastrophe shrouded in suspicion, denial, and apology, simply referred to as WHAT HAPPENED, IF IT HAPPENED. To Ailinn’s guardian, Esme Nussbaum, Ailinn and Kevern are fragile shoots of hopefulness. As this unusual pair’s actions draw them into ever-increasing danger, Esme is determined to keep them together—whatever the cost.
results.name: February's Post-Apocalyptic Book Discussion: Howard Jacobson's J

Speak and Lead is one of three Toastmasters clubs in the Rutherford area. We cater to the after-work and evening crowd. Our goal is to help You obtain success! People join Toastmasters for an array of reasons, and therefore have different goals - but the common goal is self-improvement.

Whether you're joining so as to improve your communication/ presentation skills; or to become a better leader, Speak and Lead Toastmasters is here to help! Even if you simply are looking for an activity to engage in and just want to network, you can't go wrong here.

We're a friendly, supportive group that enjoys laughing and having a good time. We do things by the book and encourage all of our members to do their best. No matter what happens, we don't give up.

Won't you join us on your journey to success? The door is open - and we'll be talking.
results.how_to_find_us: http//:speakandlead.toastmastersclubs.org
results.name: Speak and Lead Toastmasters: Speaking and Leading the Way to Success

results.description:
Due to popular demand, I will be starting another level 1 (absolute beginners) Salsa class cycle (12 weeks) on February 18th. This class will be for people who have never done any Salsa dancing before or for people who only have a little bit of experience. I will be teaching salsa on2 new york style, which is what is danced in New York.

In the meantime, feel free to take the introductory Salsa Class I offer at the La Fama Social on Fridays. It only teaches the bare basic step but it will prepare you well for the cycle. Look for the event on this meetup group.

A better/alternate way to keep up with updates, room changes, tips, videos, and in contact with other students is to join the facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/453057848231239/

Tentative Location: Pearl Studios, 500 Eighth Avenue New York, NY 10018

Room: 1201

Fee: $15 per class (cash only). You do not pay in advance. you pay when you take a class only.

Time: 8pm-9:30pm.

Here is a partial preview tentative syllabus for the first 6 weeks out of the 12:

During each week, the following concepts will be taught along with the material when necessary:

(Posture) (Weight Shifting) (hand rotation) (spotting) (pacing) (balance) (distance control) (musicality) (timing) (body coordination) (body isolations) (etc)

Week 1 (open house - anyone can join)

Footwork: Basic Step, Basic variations, upper body movement, Body isolations and coordination exercises, Timing, Music

Partnerwork: Open Hold, Close Hold, Hand placements, Correct Frame, Correct Tension

Week 2 (open house - anyone can join)

Footwork: Previous class review, Right-Turn

Partnerwork: Previous class review, Leading The right-turn, Following the right-turn

Week 3 (semi open house - only those who know the material taught on weeks 1 & 2 can join. A  special class will be offered for those who want join the cycle and need to catch up)

Footwork: Previous class review, Left-Turn

Partnerwork: Previous class review, Cross-Body-Lead and Follow.

Week 4 (closed - no new students accepted)

Footwork: Previous class review, Shine 1 and 2 (Footwork variations)

Partner-work: Previous class review, Cross-body-Lead combined with Inside Turn, Turn Combinations

Week 5 (closed - no new students accepted)

Footwork: Previous class review, Shine 3 and 4 (Footwork variations)

Partner-work: Previous class review, Open-Break Step

Week 6 (closed - no new students accepted)

Footwork: Previous class review, Shine 5 and 6 (Footwork variations)

Partner-work: Previous class review, Walk-Around Turn

Week 7 - 12

More fundamental  footwork and partnerwork
results.name: New Beginner Salsa Class Cycle (Feb 18th) (Level 1)

results.description:
If you are learning English or if you are a native speaker of English, join us for relaxed conversation and to make new friends! All levels are welcomed!

This meetup is perfect for:
-Students that want to improve their speaking & pronunciation 
-New arrivals to the U.S.
-People looking to make new friends, discuss and learn about language & culture

Topics we are open to discussing
-Weather
-Hobbies
-News
-Politics
-Anything you want to talk about 

Aspects of English we focus on
-Speaking: Pronunciation, Accents
-Listening: Definitions, Vocabulary, Synonyms
-Slang, common ways Americans express themselves

This venue has food such as pastas, salads and sandwiches ($4-$8)
They also sell Beer, coffee & normal drinks for very cheap! ($2-$4)  


Please only sign up if you are serious about attending, we remove members that do not honor their RSVP!
It will be $2 to join

Write what your native language is in the comments section!

results.description:
Please, read carefully before you RSVP!!

This will be the official Korean beginner's class. The class material will be provided. We will go through all the basics and foundations, and practice with fun activities.

Level description:

We will practice mostly the basic sentence structure using proper particles. Basic action verbs, verb conjugation, present tense, and pronunciation & speaking. You must know Hangul and can read/write comfortably

Since I need to book a space ahead, please consider your RSVP seriously and let me know if you can't make it after you said YES to come.

Please, email me at [masked] with your contact number if you can come. I will send mine so we can communicate better when the meet up happens.

The class fee will be $15 per person. Once you commit for 4 weeks series of classes it will be $40. Please, note you won't get a credit if you cancel your attendance on the same day. Be prepared for the class! :)

We may hang out and mingle after the class. I'm very excited to see you all and look forward to it! 
If you have any questions,please leave a comment.
results.how_to_find_us: Come into the building next to E,M,6 train NE entrance on 53rd and lexington ave. We are seating by the elevators.

This Thursday at 8pm I'm hosting a FREE LIVE COMEDY SHOW at the Village Lantern, right in the heart of historic Greenwich Village!!

All comics performing on the show are professionals and have been featured on Comedy Central, MTV, Late Night TV (Letterman, Fallon, Conan, etc) + MORE!! results.description:
Want to: Meet your new ski/boarding buddy?  Learn about trips, lift ticket discounts, instruction, racing, hiking, and the amazing lodge in central Vermont?  Play free foosball, pool, shuffle board or darts?  Come to a meeting (maybe buy a drink at the bar at a good price) and introduce yourself to the person* closest to you and next thing you know you will be in the middle of 6 degrees of snow-mazing separation.  Thursdays from September to April, the snow networking location is at the Knights of Columbus (KofC) in Ramsey, 8 PM.

Park across the street in the train station parking lot. Many meetings have special speakers or activities, so keep an eye out for costume parties, equipment lectures, and amazing stuff.

FYI: Attendance varies (20-50 people usually) and represents only a small fraction of our 300+ membership base.  There will always be lots of dedicated skiers and boarders who are not on meetup.com who are in the official Ramapo Mountain Ski Club. Members vary in age (8-80 year olds come to meetings), ability, availability (schedule wise), and martial status (aka dating wise) - but everyone is looking for the perfect snow partner ;0)

Ramapo Mountain Ski Club Web Site

*For first timers: ask for Elyse, Ken of Hospitality, or Maggie, our President, to sign-in, help answer questions and connect you to others in the club with shared interests.

Ski yah Soon!
results.name: Weekly Meeting

results.description:
Born and raised on Chicago’s South Side, Ulysses Slaughter developed an early and passionate interest in the concepts of forgiving and reconciliation. Devastated at age 12 by the murder of his mother at the hands of his father, Mr. Slaughter traveled a long and difficult philosophical and psychological road toward resolution. Chief witness against his father, Slaughter was obsessed with revenge against his father. After three decades of estrangement, Mr. Slaughter and his father, Ulysses, Sr., reunited and co-founded The Odyssey Project a dynamic human development campaign committed to "family reconciliation through father restoration." Slaughter is an entrepreneur, author and filmmaker behind the powerful documentary collection "Odyssey To Save Ulysses." Ulysses is not one who places abstract or random theory above the truest value of concrete experience. His journey has taught him intensely profound lessons that no one can comprehend simply through years of research and classroom curriculum alone. He has appeared on The Dr. Phil Show, The Judith Reagan Show and The Trinity Broadcast Network.

Within his many capacities, Ulysses is a thought leader and one who reconciles victim consciousness. Whether we know it or not, most of us react to life as victims. When­ever we refuse to take respon­si­bil­ity for ourselves, we are uncon­sciously choos­ing to react as victim. Ulysses masterfully facilitates reconciliation conversations where antagonistic parties learn how to take personal responsibility and discover who "other" is.

THIS EVENT IS FREE

Please contact us @ [masked] |[masked] if you have any questions.
results.name: The Art of Reconciliation by Ulysses Slaughter

results.description:
Forget what you know about forgiving. Forget what you know about reconciliation.


At the young age of 12, Ulysses Slaughter listened as his mother Clarice was shot to death by his father Ulysses Grant Slaughter Sr. Emerging from his bedroom on June 25, 1978, he watched as his mother bled from two gunshot wounds to her head and take some of the last breaths of her life. Stepping over his mother’s fallen body that day was the first, most important act in his amazing odyssey towards forgiveness and reconciliation with his father. Ulysses is not one who places abstract or random theory above the truest value of concrete experience. His journey has taught him intensely profound lessons that no one can comprehend simply through years of research and classroom curriculum alone.

Ulysses joined OneTaste in October, 2013 and helped to establish the operational container for The Council of Reconciliation. A regular presenter at OneTaste courses (including the Coaching Program, Taboo and the Intensive), Ulysses uses his powerful personal journey to challenge students and staff about infinite, “orgasmic” possibilities through radical reconciliation. Since the Council’s development, Ulysses has coordinated and co-facilitated countless community resolution conversations.

Within his many capacities, Ulysses is a thought leader and one who reconciles victim consciousness. Whether we know it or not, most of us react to life as victims. When­ever we refuse to take respon­si­bil­ity for ourselves, we are uncon­sciously choos­ing to react as victim. Ulysses masterfully facilitates reconciliation conversations where antagonistic parties learn how to take personal responsibility and discover who "other" is.

THIS EVENT IS FREE

Please contact Marissa @ [masked] |[masked] if you have any questions.

IMPORTANT NOTICE: OneTaste NY events are conscious events, hence we ask you to refrain from attending if you are under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

https://youtu.be/83YofB41jd0

results.description:
Deadline for submission of stories to be critiqued is Friday of the week preceeding the Meetup. On Saturday, I'll send out an email listing the stories to be critiqued and in what order. Print out and mark up your copies in advance.

Please make sure your manuscript is properly formatted. See our Procedures, located under the Pages tab, for guidelines and an example, as well as advice for a constructive critique. Having manuscripts already formatted makes the critiquing process easier.

Most of the meeting will be spent critiquing work of group members. There is a structure in place to make sure the critiques are as helpful as possible for everyone involved, and that the writers leave with a clear idea of what to do with their stories next.

We'll also spend some time talking about writing, sharing news and information, and getting to know one another. It's always easier to take constructive criticism from someone you know, so the social element of the group is as important as the work itself!
results.why: Writers develop their story telling skills through steady writing and constructive feedback delivered by their peers. This group is full of talented writers willing to give their time to help others develop their craft.
results.name: Sam's BSFW Short Story Meetup

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs (the roster shows 11 spots only because it includes the organizer who will play if needed). One game is 55-60 minutes. Please come a little early so that we all can start on time and play 1 solid hour. Goal keeper rotation every 5-6 minutes. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt (if you don't have red, a solid dark will do), indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence.

more info at [masked]

Thank you,

Jaime Arias

[masked]

• PLEASE ARRIVE ON TIME - 8:00PM!! Game starts at 8:15pm sharp .

• Full rules explained at the game.

Code of Conduct:

Positivity - Constructive criticism after the game is way better than yelling and complaining during the game.

Safety - Want to kick someone really hard? go take jiujitsu. We like our shins.

2 = Teamwork. It takes 2 to complete every pass.

Generosity!!!! - Not just your money (though it helps). We want clapping and good cheers.

The proceeds go to our charity network: http://ps2g.org/charities

All RSVPs are final. No credits or refunds. (It's all for charity anyway)

If the game is cancelled, request a refund by filling out this form.

If you can't afford the meetup fees, please visit our website to learn how to become a game leader. Game Leaders play for free. http://ps2g.org/gameleaders

PS2G raises money for charities that use soccer for social good restoring dignity where it's been lost through the game of soccer. We share the impact of this movement through multiple channels and promote generosity on the field through safe and supportive play.

PS2G - Local Game. Global Change.

results.description:
Running is a good workout. Running up a hill is an awesome workout. Be awesome!


Every week is an adventure in hill work. Every week is different. Some workouts include... 

30 minute continuous run. Sprint up the 0.4 mile incline, touch the graffiti wall at the top, turn around and jog back to the bottom and then repeat.

http://vimeo.com/81450322

Timed interval sprints. 45 seconds as hard as you can up. 1 minute and 45 seconds recovery jog back to the start. You will be winded!

http://vimeo.com/81966561

Obstacle course training. Workout stations with short sprints between them. Sprint to the first, do a bunch of situps. Sprint to the next, do some lunges. Sprint a bit further and do some squats. Sprint to the top and do some pushups. Jog back to the start and repeat.

NOTE: there is NO secure place to store bags, valuables, etc. Please use caution and do not bring anything you cannot afford to lose. If you do leave your belongings at the bottom of the bridge (where we start running) be aware that there is a lot of foot traffic and it would not be surprising if something "walked away."

results.description:
Join us if you'd like to be featured!

Featuring:

Matt Mankins is the founder of FairTread in NYC, where he is building modern monetization tools for the web. His team most recently built Adieu, a way for consumer to swap ugly ads with pretty photos in their browsers. Their newest product, Atri, is the best way to support all of the creators on the web. As one of the early inventors of webmail, his first company is now listed on NASDAQ as SMTP.

Previously Matt served as CTO of Fast Company, where he oversaw its digital construction and operations, playing at the intersection of new and old media, creating digital experiences for content consumers from old media artifacts. He also owned the Lorem Ipsum Bookstore in Cambridge, Massachusetts, which won several awards, including the Boston Phoenix's 2005 award for Best Bookstore Trying to Save the World. Mankins studied at the MIT Media Lab and University of Miami.

Village Tech Breakfast:

We'll do a round of introductions, followed by another round of questions for our featured guest. It's fun fast and interactive. Then we'll stay and chat as long as people like.

results.description:
Hello Fam!

This week we have the pleasure of having Tiffany Yu come and share her journey. (Special thanks to Daren McKelvey ([masked]) at R1 Labs for the intro)

Tiffany Yu is a storyteller, problem solver, and social entrepreneur. She is the Director of Business Development at REVOLT Media & TV, the #1 name in music from Sean Diddy Combs, and the founder of Diversability, an award-winning social movement to rebrand disability. Prior to joining REVOLT, Tiffany was a segment producer at Bloomberg Television. She started her career in investment banking at Goldman Sachs.

Tiffany was named one of The Wall Street Journal’s Women of Note and the New York Business Journal’s Women of Influence. She is a member of the Word Economic Forum Global Shapers and a StartingBloc Social Innovation Fellow. She has been featured in media outlets such as The Wall Street Journal, The Huffington Post, The Harvard Law Record, and more.

Tiffany graduated with honors from Georgetown University and lives in New York City.

We'll get a chance to hear about her journey, with Q&A and community shout outs afterwards! Also join us for good coffee, good bagels, and excellent conversation.

Until then, stay cool and classy... See you then!

results.description:
For coworking space, it's first come first served. You'll want to get there early to find a desk before it fills up. The space is available from 10am to 6pm. If you are planning on attending, you'll need to do the following things:

• Register at the AWS Pop-up Loft Space - https://aws.amazon.com/start-ups/loft/ny-loft/

• Once you are registered you can pick up a badge and attend any of the co-working meetups.

• Let us know you are going by signing up for the event on meetup. This also lets other people in the group know who is going to be there too.

• Remember to check the Pop-up Loft website to make sure it is open. We'll do out best to cancel meetups on holidays and days the space won't be available but you should also double check before coming out.

• While there are snacks and drinks at the space, lunch is not provided. There are a number of restaurants, delis and other places to get food in the area so plan accordingly

• These daily coworking events are self run. A co-organizer will not always be at the event. These events are designed to give game developers a free space to work so you'll basically be left alone at the space to do you own thing. We suggest reaching out to other attending through the comments to sit together or meet up at a specific time in the space.

Last thing, two times a month we'll have a dedicated space for you to come out and work as well as listen to talks and get help from myself and others in the community. Those will be different events you'll need to register for which are separate from the daily co-working space.

results.description:
We're still working our way through Mark Seemann's Type-Driven Development with F# class. We have 1.5 hours scheduled and will be able to make it through the second module -- Behavior, listed below -- plus have some discussion afterwards! 

Description

Learn how to use the strong type system of F# to your advantage – not only to check for correctness, but also in iterative development with short feedback cycles. You can use the type system to get rapid feedback about design ideas and implementation details, but also to get guidance on what to do next. Due to F#’s strong type inference, the type system of the language can be used in ways not available in C#, Java, or similar strongly typed languages. Learn how to combine the safety of static typing with the ease of development typically only offered by dynamically typed languages. The combination though, is even stronger than the mere sum of its parts.

About Mark

Mark Seemann is a Danish programmer based in Copenhagen, Denmark. His professional interests include object-oriented development, functional programming, and software architecture, as well as software development in general. Apart from writing a book about Dependency Injection he has also written numerous articles and blog posts about related topics.

Despite being a .NET programmer he takes most of his inspiration from sources across a wide range of technologies, including lots of pattern books.

Originally poised to become a rock star or (failing that) graphic novelist (in the European tradition) he one day found himself with insufficient talent for either, a master’s degree in Economics, and a desire for working with computers. He has been doing the latter intermittently since 1995.

When not working with software or spending time with his family, Mark enjoys reading, drawing and painting, listening to and playing music, as well as preparing or consuming gourmet food and wine.

Behavior 53m 2s

Introduction 1m 25s

Outside-In Development 1m 27s

Help from Types 1m 35s

Finite State Machine Recipe 1m 39s

Polling Consumer Finite State Machine 1m 41s

Demo Introduction: Itemizing States 40s

Demo: Itemizing States 3m 15s

Demo Recap: Itemizing States 44s

Finite State Machine Recipe Step 1 and 2 1m 24s

Demo Introduction: Transition from Stopped 26s

Demo: Transition from Stopped 1m 53s

Demo Recap: Transition from Stopped 25s

Degenerate Cases 41s

Demo Introduction: Transition from No Message 39s

Demo: Transition from No Message 6m 54s

Demo Recap: Transition from No Message 1m 39s

Demo Introduction: Transition from Ready 35s

Demo: Making the Transition Function Compile 5m 23s

Demo: Adding Statistics 5m 9s

Demo: Adding a Message Handler 2m 37s

Demo: Closing Over a Message 2m 58s

Demo Recap: Transition from Ready 2m 21s

Demo Introduction: Transition from Received 25s

Demo: Transition from Received 4m 42s

Demo Recap: Transition from Received 34s

Summary 1m 38s

Bryon Summers is the resident photographer for the number one hip-hop podcast, The Combat Jack Show and host of his own weekly photography based podcast, We're Getting Better. In 2013, Summers moved to New York to work for an ambitious media company. While there he wore several hats serving as an Associate Producer, Director of Photography, and Creative Services Producer he helped create daily content as well as over 10 documentaries. Outside of the 9-5 grind, Summers shot personal photography projects that eventually lead to exhibitions in New York and New Jersey.
Summers took the stage at a CreativeMornings New York event and was bitten by the speaking bug. Since then he has used his experiences in and out of media as topics to share with audiences of aspiring to progress in their respective fields. In addition to creating We’re Getting Better, Summers has held educational workshops at universities and venues.
Bryon is a Maryland native
results.name: We're Getting Better w/ Bryon Summers

results.description:
You need to REGISTER with the Englewood Parks & Recreation Department at the following link:

http://register.communitypass.net/Englewood

You may need to set up an account &/or select "Englewood, City of." After you are directed to the Englewood page, click the yellow "Register" button, then the yellow "Continue" button under "2016 Winter Programs, and follow the prompts. To register, you will need to click on or add your child's name and some other information (age, emergency contact, etc.) You will be able to pay the $40 fee online, as well. If you have any trouble, please call the Englewood Parks & Recreation Department at[masked] or email [masked].  Please DO NOT PAY BELOW.

This fee covers all 10 classes.  I hope you will attend ALL 10!!  (There is no refund for missed classes.)

Course:  Fun Fingers

Age Suggestion:  2 1/2 through 5

Class:  Getting Started

Synopsis:  This first class is the most basic.  It introduces the essentials of working in a classroom.  Learning these help both your child and the group cooperate and succeed.  This class begins to teach the children how to sit with others for circle time, how to complete a "work cycle" from choosing an activity to returning it to its correct place, and how to work at a table or on the floor.

Activities:  Pegged Puzzles, Chunky Beads, other Transitional Materials (which are self-explanatory exercises any child can do before learning specific Montessori materials) such as play dough, stamping, a pegboard, Mega Blocks

Adult Learning:  Adults will be made privy to Montessori rationale such as why we use a work mat, why particular apparatus is chosen, how the classroom set-up promotes learning, and various spontaneous information.

A Peek Ahead:  After the first class, lessons are based upon observation, so specifics are unknown.  The goal of the course, however, is to develop fine motor control and hand strength, prerequisites to handwriting.  Materials will be demonstrated to that end.  Many exercises promote these skills.  The following are some exercises that most likely will be presented and then available for the children to choose.

Self Care:  lacing cards, folding scarves, opening and closing containers

Transferring Materials:  using a spoon, tongs, a melon baller, pouring

Extra Care Needed:  cutting, tracing, gluing with a paintbrush, pin pushing

Squeezing:  using a sponge, an eyedropper, clothespins

****READ THIS FIRST || Parade Grounds Game Standards ****


Meet on field 8!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 3:00. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated 

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
Hi there,

We find ourselves challenged to maintain an environment that would encourage our kids to learn the German language and culture. Like many in the area, we live far from family that could provide more frequent interactions in German. Since our partners are English speaking, we'd like to create opportunities for our kids to experience German not only through interacting with us parents but also with others. Hence, we would love to build supporting networks with other parents and their babies & children that would like to interact and have fun(!) in German on a regular basis.


Since the summer is winding down we have to find a good place for the fall and those cold winter days : ) Any suggestions for good places for us to play or things to do are very welcome.

See you soon!

Maria & Renate

Beginner Flow

All Levels. Alignment and slow flow. Modifications taught and encouraged. Pleasure and fun, breathing, moving, smiling. Basic Hatha poses for beginners with the option to go deeper.  This class is designed to start with vinyasa flow to warm up, and include standing poses and core work. For students who feel the urge to move seamlessly from one posture to the next with the grace of a dancer and the mindfulness of a yogi. Poses are held for a moderate length of time to create awareness in the mind and body. Pranayama (breathing techniques) and meditation are introduced.

results.description:
Hi Ladies,

Happy February!

Let's get together for dinner/cocktails and then peruse the Whitney museum;.

There is not a better night to visit the Whitney than a Friday, since it closes at 10pm and you get to pay as you wish.

If this is your first visit to the museum or your second or third, the exhibits are ever changing and so is this group. You can check it out here:http://whitney.org

One of my favorite restaurants is Fig and Olive, known for it's Mediterranean style menu, elegant ambiance , and excellent food.

Check it out here: http://www.figandolive.com/menu/meatpacking/.


Ladies, in all honesty, I will need to know for sure, if you will be joining us for dinner, or meeting us at the museum. Either way is fine, but I must have an accurate head count for dinner so I can make a reservation.

PLEASE READ CAREFULLY;  when you rsvp there will be a question asked of you.

Will you be joining us for dinner?,  Just in case you don't see that question,

please email me at [masked].

If you are not sure if you are confirmed for dinner, please email me anyway.

I will be making a reservation based on the number of yeses.

So please don't RSVP  for dinner, until you are 95 percent sure you will be able to attend. I don't want to be responsible for payment if you don't show up.

 Even though I will leave the RSVP window open until Thursday, FEB 18th for the Whitney I will need to know by Monday Feb 15th, if you will be joining us at Fig and Olive. I have to give the restaurant advance notice.

SO IF YOU RSVP AFTER FEB 15TH  AND I HAVE NOT RECEIVED AN EMAIL FROM YOU BY THAT DATE, I WILL ASSUME YOU WILL NOT BE JOINING US FOR DINNER.

IF YOU ARE MEETING US AT THE WHITNEY, WE WILL BE OUTSIDE THE MAIN ENTRANCE BY 8-8:15 LATEST.


This will be a fun evening, with interesting women, great food and wine, and unique exhibits.

I Hope you will join us!.

Please keep my  cell # in case you need to reach out to me.

I look forward to a fun, and well attended event.

Cheers,

Carly

[masked]
results.name: Have Dinner at Fig and Olive and Visit the Whitney Museum  Friday February 19th

results.description:
I am a Spanish native speaker and suggest we meet at pret a manger to help you to improve your Spanish!

There is a maximum of 6 students per group and costs $10/person if the class is more than 3 people and $15/person if the class is 1 to 3 people.

My phone number is[masked] just in case you cannot find me.

Don´t sign up if you are not sure you can come.

The lesson lasts 1 hour.

Hasta pronto!

Beguinner level means: you are not able to speak without the help of the teacher, you just know really little common expresions. We will go thought the basics.

Intermediate level means: you can explain yourself with the help of the teacher, you can build up sentences but they are basic or you make mistakes on them. You have lacks of vocabulary and grammar.

Advanced level means: you are fluent in Spanish, you can explain yourself without a lof of problems. You know the vocabulary. Advanced students normally make gramatical mistakes when they talk and can forget some words, that is perfectly normal.
results.name: Spanish conversation beginner. $10/person if more 3people or $15/p if less

results.description:
Sane Energy Project Presents SANE SOLUTIONS Friday, Feb. 19,[masked]pm-9pm at the beautiful, contemporary St. Peter's Lutheran Church in midtown Manhattan.

Offshore Wind for NYC From 4 Perspectives:
• Wildlife
• Labor
• Environmental Justice
• Business

We know that for New York State to go 100% renewable, we need 40% of our energy mix to come from offshore wind (tinyurl.com/NYJacobsonStudy). But how will building the "Rockaway" wind farm impact the local communities, workers, and wildlife? Join us for a lively panel discussion and audience Q&A about how we can unite various factions behind this much-needed green energy project. 

We have speakers from Uprose, National Wildlife Federation, IBEW, DeepWater Wind ... and Professor Mark Jacobson will join us by Skype! Specific details to be announced soon!

Cosponsored by United For Action, All Our Energy, 350NYC, 350BK, Sierra ClubNYC and more to come!

This venue is wheelchair accessible. 

If childcare would facilitate your participation, please contact [masked]


Facebook event: tinyurl.com/NYCWindForum

Suggested donation to cover costs: $15
No one turned away
results.name: Offshore Wind NYC: 4 Perspectives: Wildlife Labor Environmental Justice Business

results.description:
Holistic Hangout

(typically every 3rd Friday of the month)

Relax, Unwind, Refresh

When climbing the mountain of enlightenment, growth, self-development, healing, and spirituality it can be good to stop and catch your breath.

Share, Connect and Exchange!

Meet fellow seekers off the mat, outside the circle, beyond the classroom.

Rest your 3rd eye

Revive your Chakras

Fill your heart with good company, food and drink.


COME OUT & PLAY WITH US at the WHOLE FOODS CAFE!


Stop by for a little, Stop by for a lot,

Stop by on your way or Stop by and stay,

Stop by for some stimulating conversation and a bite to eat with unique and interesting people who share an interest in the diversity of holistic and alternative news, views and practices. We are experimenting with this new, quieter space with more freedom to mingle, move, chat and exchange.

results.description:
Hi everyone, 

For our second meetup of 2016, we will try a new location. It is close to Union Square for easy transportation, has individual payment system to avoid shared checks, a large space to accommodate large group and a very low music level for conversations. Plus, they have plenty of food should you come hungry.

NOTE: You will receive a plastic card upon entering, which you use to place all your orders at the bar or counter. At the end of the night you pay off your card as you exit the place.

Is there a Cover Charge?

No! Our monthly meetup is free of charge as always.

If you like to help offset the cost for maintaining our group, you can make a $1 donation to our piggy bank, it is well appreciated but there is absolutely no obligation to do so.

Do I have to speak German?

No. While many are German natives who will speak German, our conversations are usually mixed depending on your skills and preferences.

How do I get there by train?

4/5/6/N/R/Q/L -  Union Square: 1-3 blocks

F/M - 14th St: 3 blocks

A/C/E/B/D - West 4th St: 10 blocks or tranfser to F/M to 14th St

Please look at your RSVP and change it if your plans have changed so we can keep the venue updated on our expected attendance.

I am looking forward to see plenty of you guys!!

Thomas

[masked]

[masked]

results.description:
One month from the death of writer/director Ettore Scola [masked]), Casa Italiana remembers him in collaboration with The Criterion Collection.
Screening of the new, restored 4K digital transfer, supervised by director Ettore Scola, with uncompressed monaural soundtrack of:
A Special Day [Una giornata particolare]
(Italy, 1977, 107 min.)
In ITALIAN with ENGLISH subtitles
Directed by Ettore Scola
Written by Ettore Scola and Ruggero Maccari
Starring Marcello Mastroianni and Sophia Loren


Italian cinema dream team Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni are cast against glamorous type and deliver two of the finest performances of their careers in this moving, quietly subversive drama from Ettore Scola. Though it’s set in Rome on the historic day in 1938 when Benito Mussolini and the city first rolled out the red carpet for Adolf Hitler, the film takes place entirely in a working-class apartment building, where an unexpected friendship blossoms between a pair of people who haven’t joined the festivities: a conservative housewife and mother tending to her domestic duties and a liberal radio broadcaster awaiting deportation. Scola paints an exquisite portrait in muted tones, a story of two individuals helpless in the face of Fascism’s rise.

Introduced by Antonio Monda (NYU)
Followed by a conversation with Jacqueline Reich (Fordham University) and Elizabeth Pauker (The Criterion Collection).
Free event and open to general public.
Seating will take place on a first-come first-serve basis.
results.name: Remembering Scola. Screening of A Special Day - MLC Host Mila

Who is this Study Jam designed for?


The Study Jams for Android for Beginners is best suited for two audiences:

Newbies, students, and experienced programmers new to Android can all benefit from this course. The Study Jam will follow the Udacity Android for Beginners course, and is offered exclusively to GDGs

Personal tutoring on the course material

Community setting to support course learning

Swag pack

Discount on the Android Nanodegree upon course completion

Opportunity to join Google Launchpad with completed app, pending app quality

results.description:
活动收取门票$5每人。到场并参与游戏的请准备$5现金，刷卡$6。只观战不参与游戏的，不需要交费。晚到或提前退场但参与游戏的，门票价钱一样$5。

---------------------------------------------------------

如果你玩过杀人游戏或狼人杀，却还没听过阿瓦隆，那我不得不说您有点out啦！

与狼人杀相似，阿瓦隆也是一款角色扮演加逻辑推理游戏，玩家扮演不同身份，在辩驳之中分辨好人坏人。与狼人杀不同的是，玩家人数为5 - 10人，每一位玩家都能够参与到游戏最后，不存在被杀被票死就只能干看别人玩的情景。

这个游戏考验玩家的逻辑分析能力以及彼此的信任度，是一款绝对不会让你失望的游戏！如果您没有玩过这款游戏也不用担心，游戏规则很简单5分钟就可以学会，即便您对此游戏一无所知来参加我们活动也没关系。

玩家人数达到5人即举办活动，游戏时间2月19日6:30pm - 9:30pm。如果人数多，会开两桌或组织升级等其他游戏。地点在距离Penn Station步行五分钟的XYZ IMPRESSION Studio。地址：470 7th Ave, Suite 410, New York, NY 10018. 由于游戏受玩家人数影响，请大家尽量早到5 - 10分钟，不要迟到，6:30pm准时开始介绍游戏规则。

报名请RSVP并将姓名，Email，电话私信(message)给Lisa Yu.

We've got a special Friday night workout planned with a social hour afterward at Maggie Reilly's. We'll recreate the early morning fun for everybody in and around Chelsea Park. You'll have such a sweaty, fun time you'll question every decision you've ever made to sleep in.

7:15 - High Fives / Laughter / Reminisce about the good times

7:30 - Walk on over to Maggie Reilly's (29th Street and 9th Ave) for beers, more good times, and all the extra-curricular fun.

Come make some new best friends and get in on the #HighFiveSocial. Just show up!

results.description:
This free workshop introduces the The Art of Living Foundation's seminal programs.  Over 40 million people worldwide have benefited from the Foundation's programs which teach simple yet powerful breathing and meditative techniques for reducing stress, anxiety, and fear, while increasing the potential for clarity, joy, and inner peace.

In the workshop we explore the connection between breath and meditation and state of mind.  Participants will experience the breath as a fundamental tool to unlocking a happier, more relaxed state of being with higher levels of awareness, focus and clarity.  We will experience the yoga of breath and end with a guided meditation.

Participants will also learn more about the additional course offerings at Art of Living Foundation which will allow them to develop a personal home practice. 

When:Friday 6:30pm-7:45pm

**Please arrive early for seating and registration

Where: 286 5th Ave  5th Floor (between 30th and 31st St) NY 10001
results.why: I Meditate NY is a movement empowering New Yorkers to do more things they love by recharging through meditation, a practical way to refresh every day, invented thousands of years ago. Reinvented in 2011. Our mission is to recharge New York!
results.how_to_find_us: http://imeditateny.org
results.name: Breath To Happiness

results.description:
Hola amigos y amigas:


Join our Culture, Grammar & Conversation Workshops to improve your speaking and listening skills in Spanish in a fun and natural way. During the workshops an experienced instructor will help you develop the vocabulary and grammar structures necessary to be able to converse on various subjects of interest. We have two levels:

BEGINNERS & LOWER INTERMEDIATES

The workshops are very interactive, fun and stimulating. They are conducted by an experienced Spanish instructor who will correct mistakes, explain grammar and usage -whenever necessary- and highlight essential vocabulary for effective communication in Spanish.

COST: Just $15 per person, includes: workshop, printouts (if needed), pencil, fun!

IMPORTANT: Clicking "YES" without payment does not reserve a spot - ONLY ADVANCE PAYMENT DOES - This goes for ALL our events

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

LEVEL: LOWER INTERMEDIATES (B1*)

TIME: From 6:30pm to 8:00pm

TEACHER: Jorge Gallegos

****CLICK HERE TO PAY & REGISTER****

-----------------------------------------------------------------

LEVEL:  MIDDLE BEGINNERS and UP *

TIME: From 6:30pm to 8:00pm

TEACHER: María Angélica García

****CLICK HERE TO PAY & REGISTER****

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

(*) NOT SURE ABOUT YOUR LEVEL OF SPANISH? Visit HERE for some guidance.

Need to confirm your payment went through? Read ---> HERE

Previous Spanish Conversation Workshops for small groups were a big success! Read comments ---> HERE

**************************************

DETAILS
We'll have two groups running at the same time: Middle Beginners and Lower Intermediates.

Duration: 1 hour and 30 minutes per workshop

Jorge Gallegos and María Angélica García from Easy Espanol (www.easyespanol.org) will be your language coaches. Jorge is a skilled Spanish language instructor with over fourteen years of experience teaching Spanish as a second language. María Angélica is a dynamic instructor from Venzuela with a good sense of humor, very patient and a deep knowledge about contemporary cultural issues from the Spanish speaking world.

Please be aware that late tolerance is 15 minutes (you can't join a workshop if you are over 15 minutes late after 6:30pm).

ABOUT RSVP: Keep in mind that for all our paid events, RSVP does not guarantee a spot, only advance payment does

WHERE TO FIND US

The workshops will be held at 555 8th Avenue, Suite 110 (between 37th & 38th)

See where we are in a map---> HERE

CANCELLATIONS: You can cancel and get a full refund anytime up to 48 hours before your workshop start time. Read more HERE

¡Nos vemos!

Jorge

Lets get together and enjoy the NY Skyline views from one of the most popular luxurious rooftops.

Our Next Happy Hour is at Monarch Rooftop Lounge

It is a spacious penthouse cocktail bar with clubby decor, light fare, Indoor/ heated outdoor seating & urban views.

 The 5,000-square foot venue can fit 300 revelers, a welcome feat in a neighborhood that's full of less-than-stellar imbibing options. Cocktails are by Liquid Lab NYC and you'll be able to scope out stellar views of the Empire State Building from the cushioned patio seating outside.

I hope all the amazing members can make it to the Happy hour meetup :)

Best

Rattan

results.description:
A great way to get Dharma connected in New York!

For people interested in Buddhism or meditation or just leading a kinder life who are up for meeting like minded people.

Dharma Drink is now Self Service!

The table is always reserved in the same spot - just show up and see what happens  - just like if you were hanging out meeting other Buddhists randomly in Kathamandu or India. And don't take the RSVP too seriously - people are coming now who don't RSVP. The word is getting out....

Everyone is invited! Dharma Drink is all about building community amongst the Buddhist and like minded crowd in New York City. Greg the founder of Dharma Drink: "I was inspired to start Dharma Drink by hanging out with all of the great students of all of the different lamas in Kathmandu - Kagyu, Nyingma, Sakya, Gelugpa - totally Rimey (also Zen, Thai, Theravadan, yoga travelers, and the curious - just about everyone!).  We all became great friends and learned from each other." We're there every Friday night - see you there.


Motivation:  To make the Rubin Museum Lounge on Friday night the Buddhist and like minded hang-out spot in New York.

Who:  ALL ARE INVITED.  Feel free to spread the word.  The more,             the merrier.

Time:  7-?pm
Date:  Every Friday - like clockwork
Place:  Rubin Museum Lounge, 17th Street and 7th Avenue
How to find us:  Look for a table with the small sign "Dharma Drink"                          + Lounge staff  will know where we are.

Please see the following Meetups too!

Buddhist Events New York     and

Zen / Chan Buddhist Activities

www.dharmadrink.com
results.why: Because Buddhists and like minded people are great to hang-out with.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be at a high-top table with little sign that says Dharma Drink, the high table overlooking the lower level and closest to the elevators - the lounge staff will know where we are in case you get totally lost.
results.name: Dharma Drink: the hang-out for Buddhists (& like minded)

venue.name: Some Good Wine

results.description:
Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html

We recommend getting your tickets as far in advance as possible because this event often sells out! As an incentive to get your ticket early, we will be raising the ticket price every few days. The price will be as high as $45 by the event time.

"Mingle & Taste 15 Wines From All Around The World!"
Join us for a festive Wine tasting and mingle with fellow upscale NYC professionals where you will get to taste 15 wines in a fun, relaxed environment. There will be red and white wines for all around the world along with delicious cheeses. Detailed instructions on how the wine was made with each pour!. Typically about 75% of attendees of this event come alone and 25% bring a friend. Expect more than 25 people (mostly singles) to attend. This is not an age specific event. Anyone friendly and interested in mingling and tasting great wine may attend.

* THIS IS A MULTI MEETUP GROUP EVENT. THIS EVENT IS BEING LISTED ON OVER 15 DIFFERENT MEETUP GROUPS. THE RSVP LIST ON THIS PAGE IS ONLY A SMALL PORTION OF ACTUAL EVENT ATTENDEES.

When: Friday, February 19th: 6:30 - 8:30 PM (You can arrive as early as 6:15 to check-in)
Where: "Some Good Wine"
(13 E 8th St, New York, NY - between 5th Ave and University Pl)


Also enjoy complimentary cheeses & crudités!

POST WINE TASTING MINGLE!
After the wine tasting ends we will be inviting all attendees to stroll down the street to a nearby bar so we can continue to mingle. We will be announcing the venue where this will be held during the wine tasting event. 

Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html
We recommend getting your tickets as far in advance as possible because this event often sells out! As an incentive to get your ticket early, we will be raising the ticket price every few days. The price will be as high as $45 by the event time.


FAQ:

How many people will be attending? We usually have between 25 and 40 people at this event.

What us the dress code? The dress code is "neat, casual or trendy". Basically just don't wear gym attire. What you wear to work is likely perfect.

Can I come alone? Yes 75% attending typically come on their own... some people bring a friend or 2.

Is this event social? Yes! What makes this event great is that a lot of socializing goes on and the vibe is very laid back and friendly.

Do I need to know about wine? Absolutely not... Most come to learn and to socialize.

What is the age range? This is not for a specific age range. We'll have a good mix of ages 20s-50s. Everyone always seems to find people in their peer group to hang out and taste with. 

Do I have to buy a ticket in advance? Yes. Space is limited and this event will sell out so grab your ticket as early as possible.


Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html
results.name: Wine Tasting Event - Wines, Cheeses & Mingle (Must PrePay Online)

results.description:
We should all check out this berry pizza making class! It looks delicious and we can learn a lot of different and unique "pizza" recipes. 

We'll learn to cook:
1. Blueberry Pizza- with ricotta, basil, honey, and red pepper flakes.
2. Chicken and Raspberry pizza- Similar to the Hawaiian pizza with a honey wheat crust
3. Brownie Pizza- Essentially it is a giant brownie pizza with cream cheese and berries. 

For more information & for tickets: https://goo.gl/dCeP1F
results.name: Unique Berry Pizza Class!

Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html

We recommend getting your tickets as far in advance as possible because this event often sells out! As an incentive to get your ticket early, we will be raising the ticket price every few days. The price will be as high as $45 by the event time.

"Mingle & Taste 15 Wines From All Around The World!"

Join us for a festive Wine tasting and mingle with fellow upscale NYC professionals where you will get to taste 15 wines in a fun, relaxed environment. There will be red and white wines for all around the world along with delicious cheeses. Detailed instructions on how the wine was made with each pour!. Typically about 75% of attendees of this event come alone and 25% bring a friend. Expect more than 25 people (mostly singles) to attend. This is not an age specific event. Anyone friendly and interested in mingling and tasting great wine may attend.

When: Friday, February 19th: 6:30 - 8:30 PM (You can arrive as early as 6:15 to check-in)
Where: "Some Good Wine"
(13 E 8th St, New York, NY - between 5th Ave and University Pl)

Also enjoy complimentary cheeses & crudités!

POST WINE TASTING MINGLE!
After the wine tasting ends we will be inviting all attendees to stroll down the street to a nearby bar so we can continue to mingle. We will be announcing the venue where this will be held during the wine tasting event. 

Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html
We recommend getting your tickets as far in advance as possible because this event often sells out! As an incentive to get your ticket early, we will be raising the ticket price every few days. The price will be as high as $45 by the event time.


FAQ:

How many people will be attending? We usually have between 25 and 40 people at this event.

What us the dress code? The dress code is "neat, casual or trendy". Basically just don't wear gym attire. What you wear to work is likely perfect.

Can I come alone? Yes 75% attending typically come on their own... some people bring a friend or 2.

Is this event social? Yes! What makes this event great is that a lot of socializing goes on and the vibe is very laid back and friendly.

Do I need to know about wine? Absolutely not... Most come to learn and to socialize.

What is the age range? This is not for a specific age range. We'll have a good mix of ages 20s-50s. Everyone always seems to find people in their peer group to hang out and taste with. 

Do I have to buy a ticket in advance? Yes. Space is limited and this event will sell out so grab your ticket as early as possible.

Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html

Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html

We recommend getting your tickets as far in advance as possible because this event often sells out! As an incentive to get your ticket early, we will be raising the ticket price every few days. The price will be as high as $45 by the event time.

"Mingle & Taste 15 Wines From All Around The World!"
Join us for a festive Wine tasting and mingle with fellow upscale NYC professionals where you will get to taste 15 wines in a fun, relaxed environment. There will be red and white wines for all around the world along with delicious cheeses. Detailed instructions on how the wine was made with each pour!. Typically about 75% of attendees of this event come alone and 25% bring a friend. Expect more than 25 people (mostly singles) to attend. This is not an age specific event. Anyone friendly and interested in mingling and tasting great wine may attend.

* THIS IS A MULTI MEETUP GROUP EVENT. THIS EVENT IS BEING LISTED ON OVER 15 DIFFERENT MEETUP GROUPS. THE RSVP LIST ON THIS PAGE IS ONLY A SMALL PORTION OF ACTUAL EVENT ATTENDEES.

When: Friday, February 19th: 6:30 - 8:30 PM (You can arrive as early as 6:15 to check-in)
Where: "Some Good Wine"
(13 E 8th St, New York, NY - between 5th Ave and University Pl)


Also enjoy complimentary cheeses & crudités!

POST WINE TASTING MINGLE!
After the wine tasting ends we will be inviting all attendees to stroll down the street to a nearby bar so we can continue to mingle. We will be announcing the venue where this will be held during the wine tasting event. 

Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html
We recommend getting your tickets as far in advance as possible because this event often sells out! As an incentive to get your ticket early, we will be raising the ticket price every few days. The price will be as high as $45 by the event time.


FAQ:

How many people will be attending? We usually have between 25 and 40 people at this event.

What us the dress code? The dress code is "neat, casual or trendy". Basically just don't wear gym attire. What you wear to work is likely perfect.

Can I come alone? Yes 75% attending typically come on their own... some people bring a friend or 2.

Is this event social? Yes! What makes this event great is that a lot of socializing goes on and the vibe is very laid back and friendly.

Do I need to know about wine? Absolutely not... Most come to learn and to socialize.

What is the age range? This is not for a specific age range. We'll have a good mix of ages 20s-50s. Everyone always seems to find people in their peer group to hang out and taste with. 

Do I have to buy a ticket in advance? Yes. Space is limited and this event will sell out so grab your ticket as early as possible.


Get Tickets At: http://www.ClickMixers.com/winetasting.html

results.name: Wine Tasting Event! (Must PrePay Online)

results.description:
Let's gather on a Friday night to create THANK YOU & APPRECIATION CARDS. This is the perfect way to make new friends & get creative!

We will make FOUR CARDS with amazing techniques and lots of embellishments & beautiful papers. The cards will  be cards that can be given to show your appreciation to those important people that impact your life. 

ALL SUPPLIES ARE INCLUDED in this event-just come ready to learn a lot and create beautiful art that can be shared with others. 

***This event is perfect for card makers of all levels.***

Check out Heidi's Art at: GOTHAM CITY STAMPERS

Check out the GOTHAMETTES (ART) FACEBOOK GROUP
results.name: Thank You/Appreciation Cards

results.description:
Jump start the weekend with an evening of knitting at Connecticut Muffin.  We will meet to also talk about other good knitting meetup locations so come with ideas, if you can.

Connecticut Muffin is a well-lit, welcoming cafe with an extensive selection of snacks, baked goods, coffees and teas.

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

results.description:
Join us for a warm (both the food and the people) Shabbat dinner!

Bring a guest and your favorite dairy or pareve (not meat or dairy) dish to share with us.

We'll wrap up dinner with a dessert-filled oneg/Shabbat party!

Please say what you can bring when you reply.

We can't wait to see you!

** Please reply yes if you are coming -- those who reply yes will receive the address the day before the event in a private message**


*Kashrut policy: We kindly ask that homemade food is made using kosher-dairy or kosher-pareve ingredients. Alternatively, you can bring a packaged food as long as it's marked kosher or comes from a kosher deli counter, such as Kosher Experience in Matawan/Aberdeen or Marlboro, or the kosher section of Wegmans in Woodbridge or Manalapan. If you have any questions about kosher foods, please privately message YJPA and we can clarify anything for you!
results.name: Dairy potluck Shabbat dinner!

results.description:
Please read Samuel R. Delany's _The Einstein Intersection_, which won the 1967 Nebula award. This one is Mike's pick.
"From Library Journal:
...The plot follows a race of aliens, the Lo Lobey, who colonize Earth after humankind's departure and try to make sense of our existence (good luck!). This edition has a new foreword by Neil Gaiman of Sandman comic fame.
Copyright 1998 Reed Business Information, Inc.
Review
"When Delany describes to us what he has seen, what he can compute, adduce, intuit or smell in the underbrush, our reaction is to sit bolt upright and cry out, 'Of course, I have that very wound myself!' The ability to produce this reaction in people is one of the commonly accepted and apparently valid appurtenances of genius . . . I look forward to the explosion reading this will create within you." --A. J. Budrys, Galaxy Magazine "
(Blurbs yanked from Amazon.)

results.description:
I'm presenting at the New York Mythological Roundtable Friday Feb. 19th. 

Our body tells the truth our words can't. Myths and archetypes can manifest in our physical bodies affecting our psyche and behavior. Conversely we can unfold the body and unpack layers of the myths and archetypes we've been unknowingly hosting. 

We will begin with a foundational introduction to somatic psychology and yoga therapy, then move into the experiential portion of the workshop. 

Participants can expect to learn basic theory about the importance of body-centered therapy and have a first hand experience with the mental shift physical postures can produce. 

All levels of learners are welcome. Therapist, psychologists and social workers will find this workshop of particular interest. 

Facilitator Taryn Hughes has been consistently working with the body and it’s mechanical, intuitive and emotional healing wisdom for nearly two decades. Creator of Sacred Centering she is most noted for her progressive approach to mind-body programming.

$3-5 donation. 

New York Mythological Roundtable RSVP http://www.meetup.com/NY-Mythology/events/228061258/
results.how_to_find_us: Upstairs
results.name: Emobodied Myths and Archetypes

group.name: Women Living Brightly International: NYC + Brooklyn

results.description:
All levels are welcomed.

Our sessions are 2.5 hours with a long break in the middle. Attendees will draw from still lives with a break every half hour. 

During our session I will break off with each attendee individually to talk about the work they are creating and their individual drawing challenges. 

This is the fastest way to improve your drawing skills. It is a combination of practice and theory in the same class. 

Since each attendee comes to the session at a different level and with different challenges it is my goal to work with each person individually. 

• Space is limited and the setting is ideal. 

• Refreshments are served at the long break in the middle of the session. 

• Please bring a pad up to 16x20, a 2H, HB and 4B pencil and an eraser. 

• The price is $25 paid at the time of the class. 

• All levels are welcomed.

• Please RSVP through this meetup so I know you are coming. 

I look forward to seeing you there!

Simon

Simon Levenson is the drawing instructor at The National Arts Club and teaches drawing at The Morgan Library & Museum and The Museum of The City of New York.  Please read reviews by other students of his teaching here.
results.how_to_find_us: Please ask the doorman for the location.
results.name: Friday Night - Instructed Drawing Session

results.description:
We will be heading to Pony Bar in the 70s. 

About Pony Bar:

"Our focus here at The Pony Bar is to bring you a rotating selection of the finest craft beers America has to offer.

The name “Pony” comes not from a horse but from the short beers that used to be served in between races at the track.

We won’t be stocking any imports. You may get a Belgian style beer, but it will be brewed right here in the good old USA.

We believe draft beer is craft beer, so we only carry two bottled beers, Bud and Bud Light.
We have twenty craft beers and two hand-pumped cask ales on at all times. Our in-house menu board will display the Brewer, the Beer, and the ABV (alcohol by volume) for each offering and our website & twitter page will have real-time updates to our beer changes.

Most of our beers are served in our 14oz. blue label glass. Other specialty & high ABV beers are served in our 8 oz. red label pony glass.

You can also take your delicious craft beer to go in one of our official Pony Bar 64 oz. growlers!

There is surely something for every palate here at The Pony Bar. There is also a full bar and a fine selection of wines by the glass."
results.name: Pony Bar - Happy Hour Event - In the 70s

venue.name: Rubin Museum of Art - K2 Lounge / Cafe Serai

results.description:
Bodhisattvas (Buddhists and like/opened minded compassionate friends) are now everywhere yet still hard to find.  So come join us and get connected with other bodhisattvas from the New York Metro area.  Every Friday we meet other compassionate friends at the Rubin Museum Cafe in a relaxed and easy going atmosphere.

Bodhi Lounge is a social/entrepreneurial meetup for Buddhists, or anyone interested in meeting Buddhists and learning about Buddhism. That said, people of any faith or practice—or no spiritual practice—are all welcome!  Let's all get along and learn from each other. So let's meet and have a cheerful time making new friends and/or helping each other grow our friendships or businesses!

So why are we always at the Rubin Museum Cafe and not check out other locations?  Rubin Museum is a Himalayan museum, which means mostly Buddhist art.  Thus we like this museum!  Also, by being at one location all the time, people now can just show up if their schedule opens up.  There, that easy!

This is a joint social between Bodhi Lounge and Dharma Drink.  We are always at one location; ask the museum staff for the Dharma Drink group.  If the first staff does not know, ask another. 

See you soon!
results.how_to_find_us: Ask the museum staff for the Buddhist social group!
results.name: Weekly Social with Like Minded Friends @ Rubin Museum Cafe

results.description:
One of our members has brought this event to my attention so I am posting the details. I won't be going but in case any of you are interested here is the info! Please be advised you do need to register prior to the event. See the website below for full details. 

"On the verge of a nervous breakdown" captures so well what people feel when going through trauma, life transition or high levels of stress and emotional overload. People come into therapy afraid that they're losing their minds, losing control or unable to handle basic every day things. They come to us seeking relief. What do we offer? According to Christine LaCerva, director of the Social Therapy Group, it's possible to be on the verge of a breakdown and a breakthrough at the same time. With group therapy as her primary modality, Christine helps clients in crisis to move in closer to her and the group -- to let others see and touch their loneliness, failures, and emotional pain. To let themselves be loved. And in doing that to create new possibilities. Join Christine as she shares her clinical experience, challenges and discoveries and leads us in a conversation that opens up new ways of seeing and treating people in crisis.

Christine LaCerva, M.Ed is the director of the Social Therapy Group, a large group practice in Fort Greene, Brooklyn and Manhattan. Trained by Dr. Fred Newman, the founder of social therapy, Christine is now the leading practitioner of this approach. She helps diverse groupings of people create new emotional performances. A talented clinician, educator and artist, Christine has trained in a variety of performance disciplines that she brings to her therapeutic practice to help adults and children grow emotionally. She brings her passion, sensitivity and skill to helping clients develop their lives. Christine directs the Institute's clinical training programs and leads a weekly online supervision group with clinicians and coaches who are integrating the social therapeutic approach in their practices nationally and internationally.


For more information or to register go to: 

<a>http://eastsideinstitute.org/events/</a>;

 or contact 

[masked]

results.description:
The State of Composting in NYC: Realities and Ideals

Center for Bioregional Living PDC graduate Greg Todd will present an analysis of the NYC waste stream and how organics are being separated from it, at present.  Greg will present an updated plan for a bike carting and composting business including details on an in-vessel composting system manufactured by Ecovalue Technology. Updates on the City's organics pilot, a proposal for franchising of the private carting industry and information about the Montauk Cutoff proposal will also be discussed.

Laura Rosenshine will be out of town on February 19th but has offered to call in to update us on her composting project based in the Lower East Side.

Here's a link to a recent article on this topic...

http://citylimits.org/2016/01/21/cityviewscitys-composting-program-is-a-mandate-in-search-of-a-plan/

Join us for good drinks and organic food before and during this meet up at The Commons Cafe. We will be meeting in the back on the first floor conveniently right behind the cafe!

Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup
Every Third Friday at The Commons
7pm-9pm
$5-$10 Suggested donation - no one turned away!

Permaculture is a holistic design science that is positively changing the way people think and interact with Earth systems. Turn problems into solutions by joining us in the discussion, design and implementation of projects in and around Brooklyn and the surrounding region. We are looking to create an active group of motivated beings that want to contribute to all the positive change that is happening in our region and the world. This Meetup will be lead by Andrew Faust and occasional visiting friends. Andrew is director at Center for Bioregional Living which since 2007 has been training permaculture designers in NYC and starting June 1st 2012 at their rural campus in Ellenville, NY. A certificate in Permaculture Design is very helpful but not necessary. Click HERE to join Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup.

results.description:
Come learn, practice, and speak with other Esperantists. Everyone is welcomed.

We have chosen to read The Time Machine by H.G. Wells, in Esperanto. Please read the first chapter!

http://i-espero.info/files/elibroj/eo%20-%20wells,%20h.g.%20-%20la%20tempo-masxino.pdf

During our meetup, we will have time for communal sharing of poetry, short stories, or news. It can be your work or someone else's. Participation is encouraged.


We are also in need of people to volunteer to give (15 minute long) presentations about any topic in Esperanto. If you can write something up, please contact Michael Brandini as soon as possible. The location will be at 28 East 35th St., New York, NY 10016, with the red door. Feel free to bring a snack to share. (not necessary)


Lernu, praktiku, kaj babilu kun aliaj samideanoj. Ĉiuj esperantistoj estu bonvenaj.


Ni komune eklegos La Temp-Maŝino en Esperanto. Bonvolu legi la unuan ĉapitron.  http://i-espero.info/files/elibroj/eo%20-%20wells,%20h.g.%20-%20la%20tempo-masxino.pdf

Dum la renkontiĝo ni havos komunan tempon por voĉlegi plurajn aferojn. Vi povas prezenti etajn aĵojn kiel poemoj, ege mallongaj rakontoj, aŭ novaĵoj.


Ni ankaŭ bezonas voluntulojn por prelegi pri io ajn. Se vi volas verki ion (aŭ legi la verkon de aliulo), bonvolu kontakti Miko tuj.


La kunveno estos en 28 East 35th St., New York, NY 10016, la pordo estas ruĝa. Vi rajtos porti ion kundivideblan, tamen ne endas. Ĝis tiam!

results.description:
Dixon Place presents: An evening of sharing skin stories. There’s no winning or losing here, no pressure to share. no need to rehearse, just show some skin & tell its tale in 3min or less. Baring skin & soul.

Many humans are physically changed. Some by conscious design (to commemorate that new found love; to forget that painful break-up; to show the world allegiance to an author, a musician, a way of thinking; as a reminder of living). Some by run-in with an accident or mistake (like that time with the situation with that car window) or an illness. And some by a need to just change. Every Thing has a story!

With these changes come stories. Come share a life story etched into skin! In addition to participating, audience members are, of course, welcome to simply come to look & listen.

results.description:
Let's go to the Cedar Street Grill for some comfort food in Dobbs Ferry on Friday February 19 at 7pm. I'll make a reservation for eight, and we'll be seated at 7:;30. Your $3 will secure your spot. 

Comfort food is the edible equivalent of your childhood blankie: Its warmth envelops you, making you feel cozy, lethargic, and contented. These typically warm, soothing, and traditional meals and snacks evoke a sentimental, sometimes nostalgic, feeling of well-being. Often characterized by starchiness and simple preparation, the carbohydrates, fat, and protein usually found in these dishes make a salivating trifecta.

Westchester Magazine tasted, analyzed, adjusted our belts and re-tasted (to be sure!) and compiled 67 of the most soul-warming comfort foods at Westchester restaurants. And... Cedar Street Grill consistently placed as a restaurant with yummy comfort food offerings. Soooo during this frigid month let's go! 

The mac ’n’ cheese with breadcrumbs, Parmesan, and sharp cheddar at Cedar Street Grill in Dobbs Ferry


Cheesey

Gloriously ooey, gooey, sharp, pungent, crumbly, or creamy, cheese is just about the best food on earth (besides chocolate). And what says cheesy better than mac ’n’ cheese? Many restaurants have caught on to what a wonderful vehicle this traditionally kiddie dish is, concocting their own Rolls Royce variations of the theme. Among the best is Cedar Street Grill (Dobbs Ferry) which steps it up with Parmesan, cheddar, fresh thyme, toasted breadcrumbs, and the option to add bacon or lobster. 


Deep Fried 

Whether you’re a little hungover or just hankering for naughty deep-fried goodness, this comfort-food category is rich with possibilities. 

With fried food, beer is often involved as an ingredient or accompaniment. Cedar Street Grill’s (Dobbs Ferry) beer-battered pickles are tangy sliced rounds with a fluffy coating and roasted pepper remoulade. Diners ordering fried chicken at Cedar Street Grill get a thigh, breast, and leg, covered in dense coating with branches of woody herbs, charred lemon, and a silver gravy boat of Sriracha maple syrup, made with organic Crown Maple Syrup from Dutchess County. “You can pour it, but most people pull apart the chicken and dip it,” Chef Matt Kay says. 

Meat

There’s nothing more savory for us omnivores than a slow-roasted hunk of meat, promising satiety for hours. Meatloaf—simple, familiar, and filling—epitomizes the comfort-food appeal of such dishes. Cedar Street Grill’s (Dobbs Ferry) applewood-smoked bacon-wrapped meatloaf is served with garlic whipped, skin-on Yukon Gold mashed potatoes and a demi-glace that takes days to make from roasted veal-bone stock, fresh herbs, and red wine. Shiitake mushrooms and caramelized onions top it off.

results.description:
Get ready to get happier simply by talking about happiness! It's great if you can RSVP in advance, but in case you can't, come anyway.

As a reminder, this group has two goals. The first is to explore the relationship between happiness and goodness. The second, much more fun, goal is for us to become much happier just by getting together and talking about happiness. The theory behind this second goal comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them whenever and however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group, and those are our goals. It's also very, very important that we have fun. With that in mind, let's get ready to get good and happy!


Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change 
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions 
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress 
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages

results.description:
The state of composting initiatives in NYC: Realities and ideals

Center for Bioregional Living PDC grad Greg Todd will present an analysis of the NYC waste stream and the manner in which it is being disposed. He'll also present an updated plan for a bike carting and composting business including details on an in-vessel composting system manufactured by Ecovalue Technology. Updates on the City's organics pilot, a proposal for franchising of the private carting industry and information about the Montauk Cutoff proposal will also be discussed.

Laura Rosenshine will be out of town on February 19th but has offered to call in to update us on her composting project based in the Lower East Side.

Here's a link to a recent article on this topic...

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
